title: Green Cars: Alternative Alternatives
promoTeaserSmall: These are the truly way-out choices, cars that run on CNG, fuel cells, even compressed air.
promoTeaser: These are the truly way-out choices, cars that run on CNG, fuel cells, even compressed air.
metaTitle: Green Cars: Alternative Alternatives - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Green Cars: Alternative Alternatives. Read about cars being tested for the future that have even more experimental alternative technology than hybrids and EVs. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
You probably already know about gas/electric hybrids, plug-in hybrids, and electric vehicles. (If you don't, see our story Green Cars: Deciphering the Choices.)

But what about green cars that are none of the above? The search for what will replace the gasoline engine once we've sucked the oil wells dry is still on, so in the interest of fair time, here's a look at some alternative alternative fuel schemes. Don't get too excited: these technologies aren't quite ready for prime time. But who knows what the future may hold?

Compressed Air

French automaker Peugeot unveiled the Peugeot 2008 Hybrid Air crossover at the Geneva Auto Show earlier this month. It's a hybrid designed for city driving that pairs a gasoline engine with a hydraulic motor powered by compressed nitrogen. The nitrogen is stored in a tank under the car, and when the driver decelerates or brakes, that action causes it to compress. The kinetic energy stored in the compressed nitrogen can then be used to power the car for up to 80 percent of city driving, depending on the traffic. More traffic, and thus more braking, will allow the car to be powered by nitrogen, or basically to run on air, for a greater percentage of a trip. Peugeot says this technology could get the car to as much as 81 mpg in the city, where its regenerative braking capability would be most useful.

Peugeot's Hybrid Air system is experimental for now, but the company hopes to have the technology in European showrooms by 2015 or 2016. Peugeot expects the price of the eventual production car to be in the neighborhood of $26,000.

Natural Gas

Compressed natural gas has several benefits as a fuel source. Cars that run on natural gas release up to 45 percent fewer smog-producing emissions and up to nine percent fewer greenhouse gas emissions than cars that run on gasoline. Natural gas is also cheaper than gasoline, and the vast majority of the natural gas used in the United States is also produced here, so it has that whole reducing dependence on foreign oil thing going for it.

The only production passenger car currently for sale in the United States is the Honda Civic Natural Gas, which returns 27 mpg in the city and 38 mpg on the highway. It has been lauded as one of the greenest cars on the market. There is also the Ram 2500 CNG, a natural gas pickup that is used as a fleet vehicle and recently made its way to showrooms after dealers expressed an interest in the technology. So why isn't everyone driving a car powered by natural gas? Because natural gas pumps aren't nearly as ubiquitous as gasoline or diesel pumps, so while this fuel is cheaper, it is also much harder to come by.

Fuel Cells

Cars that are powered by fuel cells use the reaction between hydrogen gas and oxygen to power an electric motor that drives the car. Water is the only by-product of this reaction, so fuel cell vehicles qualify as zero-emissions vehicles. The catch? Pumps that sell the hydrogen gas that these cars run on are even harder to find than natural gas pumps. The Mercedes-Benz F-Cell, leased to only fifty celebrities and early adopters, is only available in California because only that state has even the beginnings of a hydrogen fuel network.

Mercedes-Benz's F-Cell isn't the only fuel cell vehicle the company has toyed with. At last year's Los Angeles Auto Show, the company unveiled the Mercedes-Benz Ener-G-Force concept, a spin off of the G-Class that runs on hydrogen fuel cells. It imagines what an off-roader could look like in 2025.

While the EPA's fuel economy website dismisses current fuel cells as "far too expensive for most consumers," there may be more affordable fuel cell cars on the horizon. Ford, Daimler, and Nissan announced this year that they will be teaming up to produce an affordable mass-market fuel cell car, with hopes to have vehicles on the road as early as 2017.

What's Your Take?

Do you think these technologies have a future, or should carmakers stick with the green technology they have now? Comment below!

title: Lamborghini's Spring Collection
subTitle: Lambo style
promoTeaserSmall: Images of prancing bulls, many of them done tastefully, are all over the Italian automaker's spring collection.
promoTeaser: Images of prancing bulls, many of them done tastefully, are all over the Italian automaker's spring collection.
metaTitle: Lamborghini's Spring Collection - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Lamborghini's Spring Collection: Read about Lamborghini's spring/summer collection of clothing and accessories, most bearing the name and logo of the famous Italian supercar maker. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Refinement may not be the first word that comes to mind when you think of a Lamborghini. In the Italian supercar maker's defense, that's not exactly what the company is going for.  Lamborghinis themselves are nothing if not aggressive. Just look at the bull that is the corporate logo. The clothes, just like the cars, are intended to be "extreme, uncompromising, and Italian." But for its fiftieth anniversary, the brand seems to have taken its spring collection in a more sophisticated direction.

The items in the collection range in price from a low of $89 for a child's T-shirt to a high of $481 for a women's nylon field jacket. The collection is available online, but if you're itching for a piece of official supercar clothing and can't wait for an order to ship, any Lamborghini dealership or reseller can outfit you for a stylish weekend in your Aventador.

The Spring/Summer Collection

On Lamborghini's website, there's a new catalog featuring pictures of chic models swanning about Monte Carlo in a white Lamborghini Gallardo, dressed in garments from the Lamborghini Automobile Collection's 2013 spring and summer clothing line. These range from T-shirts bearing the name Automobili Lamborghini in bold lettering to more subdued polos and dress shirts for men and women with either discreet raging bulls or shields embroidered on them.

Supercar Materials to Wear

Lest you think the brand name is the clothing line's only connection to the marque, Lamborghini says the clothes and accessories are influenced by design elements in the cars, such as the Aventador's rear light cluster. Some are even made from materials found in the cars, like bracelets made from the same leather used to upholster Lamborghini interiors and bags (none priced below $1,000) that incorporate carbon fiber elements.

title: City Driver: Brooklyn by Lexus LS460
promoTitle: City Driver: Brooklyn by Lexus LS460
promoTeaserSmall: A week in the lap of luxury with a Lexus LS460 reminded me what a treat it is to drive in the city.
promoTeaser: A week in the lap of luxury with a Lexus LS460 reminded me what a treat it is to drive in the city.
metaTitle: City Driver: Brooklyn by Lexus - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: City Driver: Brooklyn by Lexus. Read our writer's description of a week spent driving a Lexus LS460 over terrain she usually walks in the city. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: I live in New York City, where subways and walking are the preferred form of mobility and how I like to get around the most. On an average, I walk at least one to three miles a day. But I’m into cars in a big way, too; we have three in my family, stored in various garages and on streets around the city. I am also the proud renter of spot in a garage two blocks from my house that’s adjacent to my favorite neighborhood Italian restaurant.

But, for one week of my life, the 2013 Lexus LS460 made me downright lazy. I test drive cars as part of my job as a freelance writer, hence the Lexus, but I also try to be mindful of my own carbon footprint. I believe driving should be treated like a necessity or a purposeful form of enjoyment, reserved for traveling long distances, moving big things, or enjoying as a special treat. I gave up my Michigan lifestyle, which required wheels for every move; one of the reasons I like living in Brooklyn is that everything I need is within a two-mile radius. A car is a nice option here, but not having one isn’t a deal breaker.

However, I am also a hypocrite. When presented with the weighty smart key fob that serves as the entryway to the top-of-the-line Lexus sedan, my walking feet vanished. A quick trip to the preschool: distance 1.2 miles. Must drive. A meeting in the meatpacking district: distance 2.3 miles. Must drive. A trip to the local food market: distance 0.4 mile. Why not drive the Lexus? I also drove it up and down Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive as much as possible, eating up fuel at a moderate rate of eighteen miles per gallon, forgoing the subway train to get to Central Park. Even my young son, a train buff, preferred riding in the Lexus, declaring the sparkly brown paint color known as Fire Agate Pearl his favorite color of the week.

I didn’t feel as if I had to tiptoe in an ostentatious beast just to enjoy the perks. That's what I liked most about the LS. I trod with lean, mean assertion, drawing from the ballsy power of the 4.6-liter V-8 engine, but the easy breezy action of this car seemed to come with its own built-in butler. There was the one-touch moonroof, the one-touch trunk, the intuitive park assist, the heated steering wheel, and the auto door closer. All that was missing was my personal masseuse. I could have pulled over, sprawled out comfortably, and used the Lexus Enform app to order my drive-through spa services, had I indulged in one more week of the languid life. The LS has an interior that is akin to slipping into a big, fluffy bed of Sferra 1,020-thread count Egyptian cotton sheets, all sumptuous leather and wood trim. My car came with the optional semi-aniline-trimmed interior and Alcantara headliner. Cue the ambient beats on the nineteen Mark Levinson speakers! I never wanted to leave.

Reality hit hard when an unforeseen pothole on FDR Drive strained the nineteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels and served as a reminder to stop loafing around and put my feet back on the New York City ground.

title: Design a Fuel Economy App
promoTeaserSmall: Ford wants someone to come up with an app that will let people easily track and manage fuel economy.
promoTeaser: Ford wants someone to come up with an app that will let people easily track and manage fuel economy.
metaTitle: Design a Fuel Economy App - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Design a Fuel Economy App: Read about a Ford-sponsored competition to design a new, more useful fuel economy app. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Are you an Android developer? Could you use an extra fifty grand? If so, Ford has just the contest for you. If not, you still have something to look forward to, because the contest is to create an app that could greatly improve how we track and set goals for our personal fuel efficiency.
Ford announced its Personalized Fuel Efficiency App Challenge at the New York International Auto Show earlier this month.

The automaker won’t release full details on the contest until the official launch on April 24, but it has said that the app should allow drivers to access their personal fuel economy data, share that data (presumably to Facebook or other social networks), and receive tips on how to optimize their fuel economy.

Why It's So Hard to Keep Track of Fuel Economy

Ford is stressing the "personalized" nature of fuel economy numbers, noting that results can differ widely depending on driving style, outdoor temperature, and traffic conditions. In practice, this can mean that focusing on personal fuel economy can make more sense than assuming you’ll always earn the mileage advertised on the window sticker.

Ford's interest in fuel economy monitoring is timely; the Ford C-Max came under fire late last year when Consumer Reports said the C-Max did not live up to its 47/47/47 mpg promise in real-world driving. The publication called out several other automakers as well for the same shortfall between claims and actual road results. Ford maintains that it is possible for customers to achieve the advertised numbers, which is likely where the fuel economy optimization tips come in—reminding drivers to be light on the throttle and use cruise control, for instance. Ford’s hybrid and electric vehicles already have fuel economy coaching built in, but if my own fuel economy is any indication, the drivers of gas-burning cars could use the help, too.

Ford's Development Setup

Developers will be able to work on Ford’s OpenXC research platform. That platform, along with the plug-in module created by OpenXC collaborator Bug Labs, allows third-party developers to create programs ranging from personalized radio stations to navigation applications.

Interested developers will have three months to submit their apps after the contest opens late this month. Then, from August 8-22, the public will have an opportunity to vote on the best apps before the winners are announced on August 28. Check out the details on the contest’s website.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
This story originally appeared in the September 1992 issue of Automobile Magazine.

"There isn’t a person in this country who thinks he or she isn’t a good driver. It’s our God-given right."—Roger Johnson, 1989 SCCA Pro Solo overall champion

Salina, Kansas—That would definitely be me. I’m a great driver. I’m so good that when I went to my first autocross event in Pontiac, Michigan, I knew it would be unfair of me to enter the ladies’ class. I mean, with my experience? My expertise at the wheel? Totally unfair.
Then again, trophies are nice.
I entered the ladies’ classs.
I finished in seventeenth place out of twenty-two women entered. Very ladylike, indeed.

Perhaps this sport called Solo by the Sports Car Club of America (SCCA) deserves a closer look. For instance, if these women are so damn good, why do they want to run in the ladies’ class and wreck my chance at a trophy?

The heart of SCCA autocrossing is Solo II, now in its twentieth year. At first blush, Solo II seems like a sissy sport: no roll cage, no five-point seatbelt, no racetrack, no wheel-to-wheel action. Just hop in your street car, exit the freeway at your local stadium parking lot, pay your thirty-five bucks, get into line, and drive around some pylons for two days. Any conehead can do that.

Lots of coneheads do do that. The SCCA sanctions more than 1,200 Solo II events (with up to 175 entrants per event) around the country each year for about 70,000 competitors, making autocrossing the third most popular U.S. motorsport in number of participants, behind drag and oval-track racing.

There are a lot of reasons for the popularity of Solo II:

• There is no big financial commitment—just a helmet, an entry fee that drops if you work the cones for a couple of hours at the event, and an occasional set of tires. You don’t even need an SCCA membership, unless you enter championship events.

• You can share your car with a friend at the events, making autocross a family affair or a pretty cool date.

• There is almost zero risk to your car and your person.

• Money is out there to be won, especially in the most serious form of Solo competition—Pro Solo—where the cream of the Solo II crop compete.

Pro Solo is also a parking-lot affair, but with a twist. The Pro Solo setup is actually two mirror-image courses run by two drivers at a time, so you have the illusion of wheel-to-wheel racing. Each driver gets three sets of runs; each set comprises two runs on both the left and right courses. Rather than trip a timer at the starting line, Pro Solo drivers do a drag-racing-style start—staging at a set of lights called a Christmas tree. Jumping the start will earn you a red light and a DNF rating for the run.

The best drivers shrug off DNF runs as necessary to finding that extra 0.00001 second that will deliver a win. I hated to DNF because there just isn’t that much racing time available to lose. The worst drawback of Pro Solo is that you get about eight minutes of actual driving for your two-day commitment—eight minutes divided among twelve sprints of roughly forty seconds each. Now, if you’re not very good at autocrossing, you can drag the fun out to, say, fifty seconds per run, which boosts total track time to ten minutes.

In truth, the worst drawback for me was that I was no good at it. No good at all. I don’t know what other people did while hanging around the stadium for two days waiting to race for ten minutes, but I spent my extra 950 minutes feeling sorry for myself.

Things would be different this weekend, though. After my abysmal debut back home, I journeyed to the mecca of autocrossing, Salina, Kansas, for the final weekend of the eleven-event Valvoline Pro Solo championship series.

All the top women Pro Solo drivers in the country were here, women who had been using up their entire vacation time autocrossing all summer, women who had won numerous Solo II championships over the years, women who work on their own cars. Women who had beaten my butt in Michigan.
It wasn’t going to happen again. I was going to learn all the secrets.

pages.metaDescription: Mean Jean's Humiliation is a story first published in the September 1992 issue of Automobile Magazine. It's a classic tale of her misadventures on the autocross circuit. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.
pages.name: page2

pageElements.text: The first secret, according to Lisa Kenas (1990 Solo II ladies’ class champion), a twenty-six-year-old most recently of Washington, D.C., is that you have to walk the course as much as possible before your first run, because you can’t practice and because every course is different. “I try to do at least ten laps per side before the first car goes off,” she says. This is one of the weirder scenes I have experienced: a sea of people wandering seemingly aimlessly in a parking lot full of orange cones, the early morning mist rising from asphalt that will be brutal and bubbling by noon. People holding hands, walking dogs, pushing strollers, carrying umbrellas against the heat, as they follow the twists and turns of the course. People on their hands and knees staring intently through a cone-marked corner. People running the course on foot, weaving in and out of the pylon slalom. People on in-line roller skates and bicycles. People with video cameras taking movies of the racing line, movies they will run on fast forward in their hotel rooms, looking for a clue.

Marchell Fletcher, from Colorado (1989 Solo II ladies’ class champion), says walking isn’t enough. It’s important to make accurate maps of the courses and to study them. Fletcher uses graph paper, and she marks every single cone. Then she draws a dotted line to signify the racing line. Then she walks the line. Then she revises her drawing. Then she volunteers to work out there in the cone field when she’s not racing, and she watches how the fastest men take the corners. Then she hauls out her map and revises it again.
“Nothing would make my husband, Rich, happier than if I would beat his time. He’s that kind of guy.”
“She could make money!” said Rich.

All the top drivers agreed that you need a stock car to do well, and most of them were in either a Honda Civic or a Toyota MR2. (Both Honda and Toyota pay contingency money to their winning drivers.) When you race Pro Solo in the ladies’ class, your score isn’t only based on how you do, it’s based on how you do indexed against the top men in your class. The performance envelope is very narrow in, say, a stock Civic, so a top woman driver has a much better chance of being very close to a top male driver in that car. Hence her index will be most favorable. All the girls in the know knew I was screwed, indexwise, because the co-driver of my lovely four-wheel-drive Isuzu Impulse was Grant Byers (1986-87 Solo II champion). Byers works for Monroe, and he runs whatever car he’s using for shock development work. Unfortunately, Byers is good. I just knew I would be the victim of the index.

I made my own graph paper and used a heavy pen to draw in the cones. That way, the mirror-image map would leak through on the back piece of my paper. It was a work of art. I walked the course until my feet blistered in my Nikes. (Just do it.) It was all coming together.

“I’m sorry, but that was probably a waste of time,” said Byers when he saw my map. Gasp. “As soon as the clutch goes down, that’s all forgotten. You need to walk it alone at a brisk pace. That’s the only way you can simulate the flow. All the other things you see people doing are a waste of time.”

He marched me briskly through the turns, telling me where to brake and where to stand on it and pointing out the key cones that I should memorize. “The whole idea is to keep your wheels straight,” he said. “You accelerate best when the wheels are straight. Steady speed. Let the car flow around these pylons,” he said, zipping past the slalom area. “Suck it in here,” he said, pointing to a tight 90-degree left at the finish line. I was prepared. I could do this. The course was cleared, and the race was on.

My first run was abysmal, beginning with the starting lights. You roll up to the start just far enough to light the tree’s top clear light. Then you edge farther to light the second light. You wait until the starter hits a switch and a set of yellow lights counts down to the green. Leave early, and the run is red-lighted. No score. A DNF. I stared at the starter instead of the lights. As I heard Cindy Jansen’s Chevrolet Camaro on my right roar away, I saw in horror that my light was way green. I was holding the Impulse’s revs at about 3,000, and I dropped the clutch. No drama, just an agonizingly sedate departure until the turbo snatched hold and hurtled me toward the first turn. It was a clean, slooow run.

After finishing, I went to the right-hand course. This time, I rolled out of the starting box before the light went green, earning a DNF. Round three: good start, smooth run, and I hit a cone, adding a second to my time. Round four: good start, smooth run, and I’m a full second faster. I’m thrilled. Then I find out that the woman in first place was more than four seconds faster. This, in a sport won by thousandths of a second. So much for the morning.
I sat in the staging area for the afternoon run, parked once again next to Jansen’s Camaro. “It’s demoralizing hearing you roar off next to me,” I confided to her with a smile.
“Forget about her,” barked Byers. “Concentrate on what’s in front of you. Shake your hands. Vigorously!” I did what he said.

pages.metaDescription: Mean Jean's Humiliation is a story first published in the September 1992 issue of Automobile Magazine. It's a classic tale of her misadventures on the autocross circuit. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.
pages.name: page3

pageElements.text: I DNF’d on one side, was slower on the other, and eventually improved my score by two-tenths of a second. I still managed to lose position, slipping down near the back of the pack for my last set of runs. The women at the front were going beserk. Marchell Fletcher shaved nearly a full second from her time, and leader Stacy Reitmeir was whittling away her score with each run. I sat in thirty-fourth place out of thirty-nine entries. Two of those never started. I was beating three women. Happy, happy. Joy, joy. It must be the index, I thought. I refigured the scores without the killer index. Oops. I was dead last.

The battle was on for last place. Judy Murray, in a white Mazda Miata next to me, laughed. “I could have done this well if I’d stayed in bed.” She was in thirty-second place. “You’re faster than I am,” I said as graciously as I could muster. “I am?” she asked with genuine wonder. She laughed harder.

“How do you keep doing this when you run so far back in the pack?” I asked Jansen, in twenty-ninth place. “As long as there’s someone in my rearview mirror” was her rationale. “This is actually unusual for me. Call me a victim of indexing. My volleyball coach used to tell me: ‘Win as if you’re used to it. Lose as if it’s nice for a change.’”
That’s it. I never lose. What a refreshing change that was.

The Pro Solo ladies’ class has only been in existence for three of SCCA Pro Solo’s seven years. “I didn’t run before there was a ladies’ class,” Kenas admitted. “I thought it was self-defeating. It’s succeeded in getting more women into the sport. It didn’t use to happen that you’d see forty women running an event. I love competing against women. It’s guaranteed good competition.”
“I’d run men’s if I had my own car,” said Jansen. “You can’t get to be the best unless you run against the best. I think the division should be between novice and advanced, not men and women.”
I really wanted Stacy Reitmeir’s opinion. She ended up winning the day and the Pro Solo ladies’ championship. In the process, she set a faster time than her husband.
“Why ladies’? Honestly? The money.” Reitmeir took home $5,100 in winnings and contingency money; her male counterpart won a mere $2,315.

I asked perennial Solo champion Roger Johnson why women weren’t running against men. “None of us can figure out why, in twenty years of autocrossing, there hasn’t been a woman who has won the open class, or a time set in a ladies’ class that would have won open.”
Oh, yuck. Are we saying that men are better drivers than women?

“I’m going to give myself the winter to think about going into the men’s class, just for the challenge,” said Reitmeir after she had collected her trophies and loot. “A woman has never done it in the men’s class.”
Go, Stacy, go. I’ll sit this one out.

Epilogue: As this story went to press in 1992, champion Stacy Reitmeir was still running Pro Solo in the ladies’ class in a new Mazda RX-7 Turbo. Cindy Jansen bought her own car, was running with the men in Solo II, and won her first three events of the season.

title: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring
subTitle: Five ways to share the road safely with motorcycles.
promoTitle: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring
promoTeaserSmall: Five ways to share the road safely with motorcycles.
promoTeaser: Five ways to share the road safely with motorcycles.
keywords: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring
metaTitle: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Motorcycle Safety: A Rite of Spring is the JeanKnowsCars.com guide to five ways you can be a safer driver around motorcycles. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: We’ve been saying it for weeks, so it must be true: spring is here. And that means that motorcyclists will once again be taking to the roads to bask in the warm weather. For the drivers of passenger vehicles, this means that some extra care is required to keep everyone safe. We’ve gathered a few tips about motorcycle safety to help you share the road effectively with our motorcycle-driving brethren.

1. Pay Attention

One of the Allstate’s first tips for sharing the road with motorcyclists is to look both ways to check for bikers. Motorcycles can hide in blind spots or blend in at intersections. Always make sure that you are fully aware of your surroundings and look for motorcycles before you change lanes or cross an intersection.

2. No Tailgating

This is good advice no matter whom you’re driving behind, but since motorcycles are especially vulnerable, it counts double when you’re behind a biker. Pick a stationary object like a street sign or a tree and count the seconds between when the rider (or driver) ahead of you passes it and when your front tires go by. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) recommends three or four seconds of leeway between a car and the motorcycle it’s following. Maintaining a proper following distance will give you time to react in case of an emergency. Obviously, you can—and should—adjust the three-or-four-second rule if weather or visibility is bad.

3. Motorcycles May Be Closer Than They Appear

The Motorcycle Safety Foundation (MSF) notes that since motorcycles are small, they can appear to be farther away than they really are. Since they’re so maneuverable, they can appear to be moving more quickly than they are. Just like the warning on your side mirrors tell you, err on the side of caution and act as if the motorcycles on the road are closer than they appear. That means no cutting across an intersection if a motorcycle is approaching

4. Make Eye Contact

NHTSA and MSF also noted that motorcycles don’t have the self-canceling turn signals that car drivers take for granted, so if you see a motorcycle with its turn signal blinking, keep in mind that the rider may have just forgotten to turn the signal off after a previous turn. Make eye contact with motorcyclists before you turn toward them at intersections, just to be sure you’re both aware.

5. Do What You (Should) Always Do

This should go without saying, but be courteous when sharing the road with motorcyclists (and bicyclists and other cars). Bikers have much less room for error than the drivers of enclosed automobiles, so give them a break. Don’t drive aggressively when you’re sharing their road space or cut them off. Use your turn signals and don’t make sudden lane changes or turns. Basically, drive the way you should be driving anyway.

title: Subaru's Latest Gear for a Cause
subTitle: AWD specialist dares to go beyond fleece
promoTitle: Subaru's Latest Gear for a Cause
promoTeaserSmall: Designed by a Project Runway champion, the salt-and-pepper shirt benefits HIV/AIDS causes.
promoTeaser: Designed by a Project Runway champion, the salt-and-pepper shirt benefits HIV/AIDS causes.
metaTitle: Subaru's Latest Gear for a Cause - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Subaru's Latest Gear for a Cause
metaDescription: Subaru's Latest Gear for a Cause includes T-shirts that help you contribute to charities and dog-friendly products with a Subaru twist. Read about them and how to get them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

promoLarge.title: Motorcycle Images are loaded Christina is working on

header.title: Motorcycle Images are loaded Christina is working on

homepage.title: Motorcycle Images are loaded Christina is working on

pageElements.text: On the face of it, Subaru and Project Runway don’t seem to go together: the car company makes you think about dashing through the snow (wearing fleece), and the TV show is about looking dashing. But this unlikely combination happened because Subaru is linked to the Dining Out for Life charity, supporting HIV/AIDS causes.

image.altText: Motorcycle Images are loaded Christina is working on

pageElements.text: Project Runway All-Stars winner Mondo Guerra has designed a special limited edition T-shirt with a salt-and-pepper-shaker theme to benefit the charity, and you can get it on the Subaru Gear website. True to its designer origin, it comes in a women’s (V neck) version as well as the traditional men’s crew neck. The date for the Dining Out for Life event is Thursday, April 25, when some 3,000 restaurants will donate a portion of sales to HIV/AIDS charities. Subaru is the hosting sponsor.

image.altText: Motorcycle Images are loaded Christina is working on

pageElements.text: Subaru also offers a full lineup of T-shirts, hoodies, and bags under the United by Blue partnership and, together with that nonprofit organization, promises that a pound of trash in the oceans and waterways will be cleaned up for each purchase.

And let’s not forget the dogs—we never do at Jean Knows Cars. Subaru’s “dog tested, dog approved” product lineup includes Subaru-themed collars, leashes, Frisbees, pet food scoops, and other essentials of canine ownership. We’re partial to the T-shirt (for humans, of course) with the image of a row of dogs and surfboards, backed by the slogan, “Shred waves, not tennis shoes.”
Here’s a company that knows how to appeal to its core audience: in this case, tree-hugging, cause-espousing people who travel with a sense of irony and a dog or two on board.

title: Nissan Leaf Taxis Hit NYC Streets
subTitle: Ready for an all-electric cab ride?
promoTitle: Nissan Leaf Taxis Hit NYC Streets
promoTeaserSmall: Ready for an all-electric cab ride?
promoTeaser: Starting with six, the activist mayor is hoping there will be 4,400 or more by 2020.
keywords: Nissan Leaf Taxis Hit NYC Streets
metaTitle: Nissan Leaf Taxis Hit NYC Streets - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Nissan Leaf Taxis Hit NYC Streets
metaDescription: Nissan Leaf Taxis hit NYC streets, thanks to an initiative that should only be the first step in assuring a large electric fleet in the world capital of the taxicab. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: The next time you hail a cab in New York City, it could be a very different experience from the taxi rides of the past. Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced on Earth Day that the city’s taxi fleet will be joined by six all-electric Nissan Leafs as a part of a yearlong pilot program that Bloomberg hopes will provide insight into how electric vehicles can be integrated into taxi fleets in the future.

Starting with Six

The six silver-and-yellow pilot cabs will be driven by independent taxi drivers and fleet owners who have volunteered for the program and will be allowed to turn down fares, a nod to the limited driving range of electric vehicles.

The 2012 Leaf has an EPA-rated driving range of 106 miles in city driving. New York’s gridlock will likely maximize the Leaf’s range by providing plenty of opportunity for regenerative braking and rare cause to travel at battery-draining highway speeds.

How Are They Meeting the Charging Challenge?

The city will install three quick-charging stations that will allow drivers of the Leaf taxi to recharge up to 80 percent in just thirty minutes. Some of the drivers have electric charging stations at their homes to allow them to charge overnight, but it’s likely that the drivers will have to take time to replenish battery life during their shifts.

images.caption: Yellow is only a guideline on the Nissan Leaf taxi
Nissan Leaf New York City taxi
Leaf at a charging station
Different look for the taxi's front seat
This part is similar, though
Back-seat view from the Nissan Leaf taxi

pageElements.text:
Target: 4,400 Electric Cabs by 2020

The pilot program starts just a few months before Nissan’s NV200 van becomes the official taxi of New York City. Mayor Bloomberg has said that he hopes electric vehicles will make up one-third of New York City’s taxi fleet by 2020. There are currently 13,237 yellow taxis in New York, so it would take roughly 4,440 electric cabs to meet that goal.

title: VW Smileage: Slug Bug Goes Digital
subTitle: A better answer to "Are we there yet?"
promoTitle: VW Smileage: Slug Bug Goes Digital
promoTeaserSmall: Volkswagen-driving Android users (and friends) will soon be livening up road trips with a free app.
promoTeaser: Volkswagen-driving Android users (and friends) will soon be livening up road trips with a free app.
keywords: VW Smileage: Slug Bug Goes Digital
metaTitle: VW Smileage: Slug Bug Goes Digital - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: VW Smileage: Slug Bug Goes Digital
metaDescription: VW Smileage: Slug Bug Goes Digital with a new Android app to track and illustrate your road trips online. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I don’t understand people who dislike driving. I really don't. The freedom of getting behind the wheel of a car and just taking off can't be compared with anything else. You really feel that you’re in charge: in charge of the car, in charge of the road, and in charge of your life. Why on earth would you want someone else to drive you around when you could do it yourself? It’s so liberating! Obviously, I love driving. I suppose that isn't a particularly original statement for a Detroit native, but it's true. I was a little late getting my driver's license because of that pesky parallel parking, but once I got it, nothing could stop me. It doesn't matter if I have to chauffeur my grandmother to the bank less than a block from our house or drive across town. If I have my green Chrysler LHS--affectionately christened "Betsy" by my mother--and some gas in the tank, and if I am somehow able to avoid getting pulled over for driving just a little too fast, I'm good to go.

Since I graduated from the University of Michigan, in April 2012, Betsy has taken me everywhere. She has been my steadfast companion on trips to buy more supplies for various sewing projects, leisurely drives along Jefferson/Lakeshore Drive in Grosse Pointe Shores, Michigan, and frequent jaunts to the bookstore to buy yet another copy of Hamlet, a 500-plus-page book on Elizabeth I, or a good book on British history that isn’t as dry as a piece of chalk…And, yes, there is a little bit of theme there. Not only am I a bibliophile, but I’m also a self-proclaimed Anglophile who loves Shakespeare and Elizabethan verse and one day plans to see the Houses of Parliament, visit the Tower of London, and, perhaps most important, eat real fish and chips. If only I could drive Betsy "across the pond…"

pageElements.text: If you’re planning on taking a road trip or two this summer, there’s something Volkswagen wants you to download before you load everything into the car.

Volkswagen's free Smileage app will be out this summer for Android phones only. Co-developed with Google, it's a fresh, funny way to track and share your adventures behind the wheel. The term "smileage" is the automaker's way of signaling that it's all about the fun factor. Using the app, you can document and share experiences on the road whether you drive a VW or not.

Slug Bugs, and Much More

Just sync the app with your car, and from then on it will automatically connect and track your driving route while running in the background. For every drive you take while connected, the app will give you a trip summary and add up your Smileage score.

Using your Google contacts list, you can let friends watch and comment on your travels in real time. Increase your Smileage number by sharing more information, tagging friends who are in the car with you, posting photos, and sharing comments.

Shorter trips, like your commute to work, will most likely trigger lower Smileage ratings than more adventurous weekend drives. For longer trips, you can choose to use Smileage in trip mode, which will add your trip photos and videos to an interactive map that records your route. Friends can experience your travels with you and comment on them in real time.

You knew there was a Slug Bug angle, and there is: every time your car passes another one that’s also using the Smileage app, you get a virtual badge that shows a punching hand. You can also earn virtual stickers like this twins icon (right), indicating you’ve passed a VW that’s just the same as yours. Sounds like fun!

title: 2013 BMW M3: My Orange Crush
subTitle: How do you feel about a car this bright?
promoTeaserSmall: How do you feel about a car this bright?
promoTeaser: This is one sweet piece of citrus. Plus: California dealer's special stripe job on another orange M3.
metaTitle: 2013 BMW M3: My Orange Crush
metaDescription: 2013 BMW M3: My Orange Crush is the story of a Lime Rock Park limited edition of the M car, paired with the tale of a California dealer's project M3, also orange, and with a special striped paint job. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Being the sister website to Automobile Magazine allows us front-row seats to a rotating selection of the latest vehicles. Since we share a building, their fleet of vehicles is literally right outside our windows. We have noticed the infusion of candy colors into the recent lineup of vehicles, and frankly, we love it.

When a 2013 BMW M3 coupe—one of a limited set of 200 Lime Rock Park edition cars—arrived in fiery orange, we took notice. We quickly snapped a photo of Jean showing her love for this sweet piece of citrus and posted it on our Facebook page. Her love ran so deep that she was inspired to infuse new orange items into her wardrobe (notice the shoes at right). When Jon Seizinger of Center BMW in Sherman Oaks, California, spotted our post on Facebook, he shared photos about a project car that his dealership has created. The dealership's 2011 E90 M3 is modified to increase performance and illustrate to customers ways that their dealership can tweak M-series cars. In spite of the modifications, the project M3 is still covered under a standard four-year/50,000-mile warranty and is eligible for complimentary maintenance.

Paint Stripes as Homage

The part of the project that truly interested me was the paint treatment. Seizinger shared the attention to detail that went into the paint scheme. "The stripes on the car were hand painted by a local pinstripe artist here [in California]. The colors are traditional BMW M-series colors and were hand applied using different brushes and techniques. We wanted each stripe to have an individual character and feel to it, much like we wanted our car to have. We wanted to evoke the passion of something created by hand in the same way a painting is painted or a sculpture is sculpted. Not temporary and cheap like [a] vinyl sticker. It also pays homage to the way racing stripes were hand applied with brushes in the early days of racing and speed records.” In a nutshell, the car looks like it should be parked in your living room to show what great taste you have in art. Take a look at their videos.

Fun on Campus

Here in Ann Arbor, I took advantage of the opportunity to take our M3 for a quick zip around town. I was pleased to find that the steering wheel is covered in Alcantara; as JKC readers may remember, I have compared it to flannel for the hands. The double-clutch automatic transmission with paddle shifters made driving this performance monster more like driving a pussycat. I was glad not to be grinding gears accidentally as I maneuvered around the student pedestrians on the University of Michigan campus. I attracted quite a bit of attention from the students, who usually don’t seem to notice that I exist. I wasn’t sure if it was because of my new haircut or the color of this little whip. It could also have been the engine growl as I played with the paddle shifters.
The ride was a little harsh on the badly potholed spring roads, and I imagined how sweet it would be to take a few laps on the ultra-smooth Lime Rock track instead.

The BMW-Lime Rock Connection

The M3 I was driving is a joint project of BMW and Skip Barber, the Lime Rock Park owner and racing-school magnate. This is the first time Lime Rock has partnered with any manufacturer. The model we drove is priced at $80,295, but since it is one of only 200, it stands to reason that each one will be snatched up quickly.

As Michigan struggles its way into spring, it lifts our spirits to see something bright outside. But the new candy-colored paint jobs that I am seeing increasingly on the road made me wonder: would I get sick of the attention that a bright orange car would garner? What about driving around in a car that was festooned with an outrageous paint job?

images.caption: Center BMW's M3
Stripes are individually painted.
Center BMW's Jon Seizinger says the stripes are all traditional BMW M colors.
Meanwhile, back in Ann Arbor, Jean got new shoes and brought out the orange sweater.

title: Is Your Dog One of the 98%?
subTitle: We’re not just talking to Mitt Romney here: if your dog is among the 98 percent that ride unrestrained, it’s time to think that one over.
promoTitle: Is Your Dog One of the 98%?
promoTeaserSmall: We’re not just talking to Mitt Romney: if your dog rides loose in the car, you should reconsider.
promoTeaser: We’re not just talking to Mitt Romney: if your dog rides loose in the car, you should reconsider.
metaTitle: Is Your Dog One of the 98 percent that are unrestrained in the car?
metaDescription: JeanKnowsCars.com explains the importance of restraining a dog while it travels in the car with you.

pageElements.text: Mitt Romney may be the poster child for bad behavior when it comes to dogs and road trips, thanks to a long-lived story about a 1983 family trip when his family’s Irish setter rode in a crate on the roof of the station wagon. It was a real-life version of Aunt Edna in the movie National Lampoon’s Vacation, and both late-night TV comedians and animal rights groups took notice.

images.caption: "Pet lifestyle expert" Charlotte Reed and her golden retriever, Hannah, demonstrate proper use of a safety harness in a Chevrolet Equinox during Pet Day at the 2012 New York Auto Show last April. (Diane Bondareff/AP Images for Chevrolet)

pageElements.text: That story strained the boundaries of outrageousness—but it turns out that most dog owners could stand to reconsider the way they travel in cars with their pets. The organization Paws to Click, which promotes safer pet travel, says 98 percent of dogs travel unrestrained in vehicles—and that there’s an accident every eighteen minutes because of a loose animal. That adds up to an estimated 30,000 driving accidents per year.

Safety advocates warn that a 60-pound dog traveling at 35 mph can turn into the equivalent of a 2,700-pound projectile in a crash. Dogs should be secured with a harness that allows them to sit or lie down but will keep them restrained in an accident, says Paws to Click, which is related to a company that actually sells said harnesses. That doesn't mean it's not a really good idea, though!

One possible source of those accidents could be distracted driving that is caused by the presence of the dog in the car. A 2011 study by AAA and Kurgo, a pet-supply company, reported that 52 percent of surveyed drivers admitted to having petted their canine companions at some time instead of paying attention to the road, while another 17 percent of drivers said they allow the dog to sit in their lap while driving.
Other behaviors noted in the study include the mildly alarming “reaching into the back seat to interact with the dog,” along with giving the dog treats and taking a photo of the dog while driving.

Some carmakers, such as Subaru of America, offer optional pet barriers for the cargo area. The Japanese automaker even sells dog bandanas, collars and collapsible water bowls on its Web site. Subaru says seven out of ten Subaru owners have a pet.

Automakers occasionally roll out canine-friendly special models. Before it discontinued the Element, Japanese automaker Honda advertised a Dog Friendly package for the Element. It was equipped with a soft floor surface to be gentle to dogs’ legs and paws, along with a spill-resistant water bowl, a soft-sided kennel, and an integrated ramp that could be accessed with the rear tailgate down.

For now, you’ll probably have to customize your own vehicle with pet-friendly items found in pet stores or online from suppliers. Some outfitters are even selling water bowls for dogs that fit in a vehicle’s cupholder.

Bottom line: Until they learn how to drive, all four of Jean’s unruly dogs (Lou, Stella, Bob and Ray) ride in crates—inside the car, of course—during road trips, just as you see in the photo. How about yours?

title: Name-Brand Stereos with Surround Sound
promoTeaserSmall: If you’re driving around in a fifteen-year-old car with a tape deck and a finicky AM/FM radio, you’re missing out.
promoTeaser: If you’re driving around in a fifteen-year-old car with a tape deck and a finicky AM/FM radio, you’re missing out.
metaTitle: Name-Brand Stereos with Surround Sound - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Name-Brand Stereos with Surround Sound: Learn more out how auto manufacturers are integration high-end audio systems and name brand stereos into their cars from the factory at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: CD players are practically a thing of the past, replaced by USB ports to hook up iPods and in-car hard drives that allow your personal music collection to go wherever you go. The next step in the sound system arms race is the proliferation of name-brand stereos as a top-of-the-line option in many cars.

Several carmakers are already in on the game. Dr. Dre became Chrysler’s second rap star spokesperson when he appeared in an ad introducing the Chrysler 300S with Beats by Dre audio system. The 2013 Fiat 500 Turbo will also showcase Beats by Dre. Audi offers an optional Bang & Olufsen stereo for the low, low price of $850. That configuration boasts nineteen – nineteen! – speakers in the A8, including spaceship-like tweeters that rise from the dashboard.

The Bang & Olufsen setup essentially turns the car into a private concert venue, providing you’ve got high-quality music on your iPod and not illegally downloaded swill. Pirated music is typically downloaded as a small file to make it more manageable for your computer and harder for enforcement agencies to trace, but this also means that you lose the “it sounds like they’re standing right next to me!” moment that larger, higher quality (read: legally acquired) files can inspire. We recommend you pony up for legal tunes if you’re going to spend hundreds on a swanky in-car stereo.

images.caption: 2013 Fiat 500 Turbo is getting Dr. Dre's Beats audio system.
That elegant but edgy Dre look, well known from the headphone product line, makes it inside the Fiat.
2012 Beetle with Fender audio goes for basic black.
Fender name already makes everything sound better.

pageElements.text: Volkswagen has gone even further and created an entire special edition Beetle inspired by Fender. The new Beetle’s design is a throwback to the 60’s and 70’s era Bugs. It’s painted metallic black and sports a seriously cool starburst-trimmed dash, a nod to your inner rock star. As far as we’re concerned, the Fender Beetle hasn’t reached its true potential until you’ve played the Grateful Dead’s Woodstock performance (originally blasted through a stack of tie-dyed Fender amps) while driving through the sunshine-y countryside. You can pretend it’s 1969 again, but this time the cars are better.

title: Where to Find Driving Moccasins
promoTeaserSmall: Just because you shouldn’t drive in your stilettos doesn’t mean you have to go barefoot.
promoTeaser: Just because you shouldn’t drive in your stilettos doesn’t mean you have to go barefoot.
metaTitle: Where to Find Driving Moccasins - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Where to Find Driving Moccasins: Check out some of these fashionable, yet practical, driving moccasins to keep your feet comfy on longer trips.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Just because you shouldn't drive in your stilettos doesn't mean you have to go barefoot. Instead of getting your clean feet all over your dirty gas pedal (or vice versa) you can slip into some fashionable, comfortable driving moccasins for your journey. Finding drivers at a department store should be easy, with dozens of styles offered by brands across the price spectrum.

For the budget conscious, Halogen offers a few brightly colored styles for under $100, while Frye and Michael Kors have high quality options for around $200. If money is no object, Tod's has the best selection for women, with leather and suede moccasins ranging in price from $400 for a colorful-but-basic pair to $1325 for a limited edition, hand-embroidered pair - for the "demanding and unconventional" woman.

Men will find their best selection at Gucci, with shoes available in exotic leathers like ostrich and python. The most expensive pair is an extremely suave set of crocodile loafers with bamboo accents for a cool $1850. If you're looking for something more obviously car-related, Puma sells a line of supercar-inspired driving shoes for around $100. Crocodile leather they're not, but still fashionable in their own right.

images.caption: Tod's Specials
Classic Gucci Look
Prada Driver

title: 2013 Toyota Matrix
subTitle: Toyota’s attempt to cool up the Corolla comes up short.
promoTeaserSmall: Toyota’s attempt to cool up the Corolla comes up short.
promoTeaser: Toyota’s attempt to cool up the Corolla comes up short.
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Matrix - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota Matrix here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Few, if any, car companies have a product family as large as Toyota, which has at least sixteen unique models (and that’s not counting its three recently introduced Prius models or five Scion-branded cars). As anyone from a very large family can likely attest, it’s challenging for each member to stand out. Such is the case with the poor Matrix, essentially a tall Corolla wagon styled like a crossover. Splitting the difference between the bargain-basement Yaris and the big-boned, Camry-based Venza in body style and price point, the Matrix is ideally packaged for the  young family and the empty nester. But evidence of willful neglect on the part of the parent company shows up in the general lack of updates Toyota has given the Matrix since its last redesign four years ago. The 2013 changes are mostly limited to audio systems with Bluetooth and USB connectivity (at last!), and a touchscreen interface for the upgrade system. All-wheel drive remains available, as do two four-cylinder engine choices: a 132-horsepower 1.8-liter and a 158-horsepower 2.4-liter—but, thanks in part to subpar transmissions, the Matrix remains less than competitive in fuel economy. Factor in a conspicuously cheap interior and lack of overall pizzazz, and it’s easy to understand why the Matrix has a tough time standing out.
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Volkswagen Golf
2. Hyundai Elantra GT
3. Kia Soul

Looks:
1. Snazzier styling on S model.
2. Many TRD accessories available.

New for 2013:
1. Base audio with Bluetooth and USB connectivity.
2. Display audio with touchscreen interface available.
3. Cruise control standard on LE model.

title: 2013 Infiniti FX
subTitle: The 2013 Infiniti FX line puts the “sport” in sport-utility vehicle, but that may make it an impractical choice for some families.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Infiniti FX line puts the “sport” in sport-utility vehicle, but that may make it an impractical choice for some families.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Infiniti FX line puts the “sport” in sport-utility vehicle, but that may make it an impractical choice for some families.
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti FX Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti FX here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Infiniti FX37 and FX50 are among the sportiest of the sport-utility vehicles and among the best when it comes to turning heads and tackling twisty roads. But some families may find they sacrifice comfort for the sake of looks and performance capabilities. The cabin is somewhat cramped, there is limited cargo room in the rear and kids may gripe that they can’t see too well from the rear seat. The ride quality in the FX line may be a bit too harsh for commuters and the school carpool as well. Still, performance is top notch with the base FX37 model getting a new standard 325-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine. Rear-wheel drive is standard on the base model and all-wheel drive is optional. The top-of-the-line FX50 with all-wheel drive gets a beefy 390-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 engine. Both engines are linked to a standard seven-speed automatic transmission. Both models have double-wishbone front and multilink rear suspensions and large four-wheel disc brakes. The cabin is richly appointed and there are lots of extras like optional sport seats that hold the passengers in place during hard cornering and make the driver feel like she’s Danica Patrick. Solid magnesium paddle shifters are optional and enhance the FX’s performance-oriented personality. The FX line may not be the best choice for hauling your kids and pets, but it does have one unusual accessory that would be perfect for sleepovers: a “hatch tent” that converts the cargo area into a sleeping area.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW X6
2. Porsche Cayenne
3. Land Rover Range Rover Sport

Cool Tech:
1. Moving object detection added to Around View system for 2013.

New for 2013:
1. FX37 model replaces FX35 and includes standard 325-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6.
2. Iridium Blue exterior color offered for all models except Limited Edition.
3. Limited Edition available only with Moonlight White with Graphite interior color combination.
4. Java interior color available with Liquid Platinum and Graphite Shadow exterior colors.

title: 2013 Land Rover LR2
subTitle: The 2013 Land Rover LR2 gets a smaller engine and a bigger sticker price.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Land Rover LR2
promoTeaser: 2013 Land Rover LR2
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover LR2  Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Land Rover LR2 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Poor fuel economy was one of the big concerns about the outgoing Land Rover LR2, which returned just 15 mpg city. But big changes are on tap for the new model year as the 2013 LR2 gets a smaller engine with an eye toward improved fuel economy. The baby Land Rover gets a new 240-horsepower turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine replacing the previous 3.2-liter inline six-cylinder engine. The new engine is borrowed from the 2012 Range Rover Evoque and is 88 pounds lighter than the outgoing inline six-cylinder engine it replaces. The engine is linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. The EPA has yet to provide the most critical information about the redesign – namely, the fuel economy, but the numbers are expected to be significantly better. In the meantime, buyers should be prepared to shell out more for the 2013 model, since the base crossover gets a $700 price increase. The 2013 Land Rover LR2 starts at $37,250, which is still cheaper than the BMW X3, one of its chief rivals. The LR2 gets a mini- makeover said to give it a sportier look. The LR2’s cabin also borrows items from the Evoque, including a new center console. Off-roaders will appreciate the fact that, despite the overhaul, the LR2 retains the same 8.3-inch minimum of ground clearance to play hard on rocky, sandy, rutted, or muddy terrain.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW X3
2. Audi Q5
3. Infiniti EX37
4. Mercedes-Benz GLK

Cool Tech:
1. Up-level HSE model is equipped with a rearview camera with “hitch assist,” a graphic superimposed on the camera showing the position of the tow ball, a must for anybody hauling a boat or trailer.

New for 2013:
1. New 240-horsepower turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine.
2. New exterior look.
3. New lighting, front and rear.
4. Three new exterior colors: Aintree Green, Havana and Mauritius Blue.
5. New center console with a seven-inch color touchscreen.
6. Original Terrain Response dial replaced by buttons.

title: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Sport
subTitle: The 2013 Range Rover Sport can go off-roading but prefers the pavement.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Sport
promoTeaser: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Sport
metaTitle: 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Sport Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Land Rover Range Rover Sport here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: You may feel like the Duchess of Cambridge in the 2013 Range Rover Sport, one of the most compelling vehicles in the Land Rover lineup. Like Kate Middleton, who can throw an inexpensive sweater over a designer gown and look great, the Range Rover Sport, with its understated British elegance, provides an ideal blend of performance, style, capability, and value. It slots in between the Range Rover Evoque and the full-size Range Rover and gets lots of kudos for its modern interior, great acceleration, and handling, along with its excellent driving position that provides a commanding view of the road. You may need access to the Queen’s treasury, though, when it comes to the gas pump. At its worst, the 2013 Range Rover Sport returns just 12 mpg in city driving and 17 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. The Range Rover Sport is equipped with either a 375-horsepower 5.0-liter V-8 engine or a supercharged 510-horsepower V-8 engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. It features standard full-time all-wheel drive and a Terrain Response system. Some buyers may object to the firm ride, but the Range Rover Sport should be on your shopping list if you need something to take you from the trail to the country club with ease. However, it’s not cheap, ranging in price from around $60,000 to $86,000.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW X5
2. Mercedes-Benz M-Class
3. Jeep Grand Cherokee SRT8
4. Porsche Cayenne

Cool Tech:
1. A “say what you see” intuitive voice control for navigation and infotainment.

New for 2013:
1. New Supercharged Limited Edition and GT Limited Edition.
2. Newly optional towing package.

title: 2013 Aston Martin Vantage
subTitle: The Vantage speaks in the discerning dialect of great British sports cars.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Aston Martin Vantage
promoTeaser: 2013 Aston Martin Vantage
metaTitle: 2013 Aston Martin Vantage Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Aston Martin Vantage Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Vantage is the Topshop of the Aston Martin lineup – very Kensington meets Kate Moss. In the gold plated garage of super cars, the Vantage is nothing to sneeze at. In fact, it somehow manages to come off as more posh than some of its older, pricier, and overloaded siblings. It’s more petite than a DBS, and therefore spunkier. Driving the Vantage is all fun and games with the ability to go 0 to 60 mph in 4.7 seconds. If you bump up to the powerful 510-horsepower V-12 Vantage, you’ll have to brush up on your standard driving skills, whereas the V-8 is offered in both a six-speed automated manual and a six-speed manual transmission. The tradeoff for that tomfoolery at the wheel is an interior that fits like a pair of skinny jeans.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Porsche 911
2. Audi R8 Coupe
3. Chevrolet Corvette ZR-1

Cool Tech items
1. The V-12 Vantage features carbon-fiber body add-ons, carbon-fiber sill plates, a sport suspension, and Alcantara seat inserts.
2. The Vantage has an integrated Apple iPod connector and a USB connector with waveform audio.
3. The sound system is designed to work with Windows Media Player and MP3 audio files.

Looks
1. Full-grain leather interior and optional Alcantara trimmed steering wheel.
2. The V-12 Vantage features carbon-fiber body add-ons.
3. The carbon-fiber bonnet vents aid performance and add a distinct flourish.

title: 2013 Nissan 370Z
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan 370Z boosts your street cred, but it may be too hard-edged for some.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan 370Z
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan 370Z
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan 370Z Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan 370Z here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Nissan 370Z has built a solid reputation as a serious, yet affordable sports car. The “Z,” which comes in coupe and convertible models, is designed for driving pleasure and doesn’t disappoint with a stiff suspension, powerful brakes and a throaty engine, but the 2013 models will put a bigger dent in your bank account. The top-of-the-line 2013 Nissan Nismo 370Z starts at $43,800, including shipping, reflecting a $1,360 price increase over the outgoing model. The carryover models get several upgrades including a refreshed front fascia with vertical LED daytime running lights – except on the Nismo 370Z – a new eighteen-inch wheel design for the 370Z Coupe and two new colors – Magma Red and Midnight Blue. The 370Z and 370Z Touring get the standard 332-horsepower 3.7 liter V-6 engine and either a six-speed manual transmission with an optional synchronized downshift rev matching system or a seven-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. The 2013 Nissan Nismo 370Z gets a 350-horsepower 3.7 liter V-6 engine with a six-speed manual transmission. Be prepared for a stiff ride on public roads, a rather noisy engine, and limited rear visibility. But if you’re looking for classic sports car styling and a car that takes fun seriously, the Z is the way to go.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Audi TT
2. Chevrolet Camaro
3. Ford Mustang
4. Infiniti G37

Cool Tech:
1. Close-ratio six-speed manual with optional SynchroRev Match on 370Z Roadster Touring only.

New for 2013:
Nissan 370Z Coupe and Roadster:
1. Revised front fascia with LED daytime running lights.
2. New Midnight Blue and Magma Red exterior colors.

Nissan Nismo 370Z:
1. New optional Bose package with six speakers.
2. Red Finish caliper color.
3. New Magma Red exterior color.

title: 2013 Nissan Altima
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Altima kicks it up a notch in the midsize sedan segment with a major redesign that includes an overhaul in the cabin.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Altima
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Altima
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Altima Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Altima here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Altima is shaking up its considerable competition in the mid-size sedan segment with new sheetmetal, a revamped cabin, and a revised four-cylinder engine that’s more powerful and efficient. A new grille and projector-style headlights give the Altima a more dramatic face, with LED taillights standard on uplevel models. The Japanese automaker has carried over the 270-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 engine in the Altima, but has revised the 2.5-liter four-cylinder, increasing output from 175 to 182 horsepower. A redesigned Xtronic continuously variable transmission boosts fuel economy in both engines – to 27 mpg in city driving and 38 mpg on the highway on the four-cylinder, according to the EPA. The Altima’s cabin gets dolled up with a new articulated seat design, available in cloth or leather, as well as a new advanced Drive-Assist Display. The Altima offers good handling and a compliant ride. Nissan expanded the Altima range with seven trim levels for 2013.The four-cylinder models get either sixteen-inch steel wheels or seventeen-inch alloy rims, while the six-cylinder models come with eighteen-inch alloys. Available safety technologies are plentiful and include blind spot warning, lane departure warning, and moving object detection. The Altima’s changes are impressive, but the mid-size sedan wars are heating up, with the debut of a redesigned 2013 Ford Fusion and 2013 Honda Accord.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Ford Fusion
2. Honda Accord
3. Toyota Camry
4. Hyundai Sonata

Cool Tech:
1. Easy Fill Tire Alert honks horn when correct tire pressure is reached.
2. Optional text-messaging assistant (but it doesn’t work with iPhone).

New for 2013:
1. New sheetmetal.
2. Revamped cabin.
3. Revised four-cylinder engine.

title: 2013 Audi Q5
subTitle: Audi’s first crossover still holds up
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Audi Q5
promoTeaser: 2013 Audi Q5
metaTitle: 2013 Audi Q5 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cas
metaDescription: 2013 Audi Q5 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: By far the most exciting thing to happen to the Audi Q5 in 2013 is the addition of a hybrid option to the existing models.  The hybrid will increase the Q5’s already strong gas mileage (20 mpg in the city, 28 mpg on the highway) and add yet more options to the versatile crossovers. Last year’s unsatisfactory V-6 engine will be replaced by a supercharged 272-horsepower option. Buyers can also stick with the previously successful four-cylinder engine.  The Q5 also makes use of Audi’s famous quattro all-wheel drive. A quintessential crossover, the Q5’s exterior avoids the boring trappings of a sedan without looking like a hulking SUV. This design has proved effective in the past, with the Q5 boasting Audi’s second-best sales. In addition to changes to engines, the Q5 has had some improvements to the interior. New aluminum trim options make the inside more attractive, while available Audi Connect technology means the Q5 can access the Internet and connect with Google Maps.
