Audio controls have also been integrated into the steering wheel for greater convenience.  The new Q5 will also sport Audi’s aggressive and unmistakable new grille and headlight design.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Acura RDX
2. BMW X3
3. Lexus RX

Cool Tech:
1. New supercharged powertrain option.
2. Available Audi Connect technology.
3. Standard Sirius XM radio.

Looks:
1. Aggressive-looking headlamps and front grille.
2. Nine exterior color options with four available trim colors.
3. Interior wood trim with brushed aluminum accents.

New for 2013:
1. New hybrid model.
2. Interior upgrades.

title: 2013 Bentley Continental Flying Spur
subTitle: The four-door Flying Spur sedan is a more pronounced take on the Continental GT.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Bentley Continental Flying Spur
promoTeaser: 2013 Bentley Continental Flying Spur
metaTitle: 2013 Bentley Continental Flying Spur Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Bentley Continental Flying Spur Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Flying Spur is a plus-size model. It weighs a whopping 5,456 pounds, but here is a super car that carries its weight well. While this hefty Bentley is big, it’s certainly no slowpoke. The Flying Spur reaches a top speed of 195 mph and the souped-up Spur Speed zooms up to 200 mph, and both do so with considerable grace and nuanced handling. The speed of the Spur in particular defies all logic – it’s a big car with excellent performance statistics. The Mulsanne may have edged it out on the flagship’s prestige category, but the Flying Spur is more than a dignified contender. Lambswool, leather and wood are Bentley calling cards found in the interior. The Flying Spur is twice the price as Mercedes-Benz S Class, but is also twice as refined in more subtle ways. A big engine, all-wheel drive and the extra brawn have their drawbacks at the pump — it gets 10 mpg city and 17 mpg highway. But if you’re Bentley bound, the gas bill probably isn’t your preeminent concern. Bentley has also improved its technology and now features top-of-the line entertainment and navigation. The Flying Spur is the super car that’s designed to blend in. It’s the sleep agent.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Rolls-Royce Ghost
2. Aston Martin Rapide
3. Maserati Quattroporte

Cool Tech
1. The Series 51 affords all the high-tech trappings in a singular package.
2. At one time the Flying Spur was lacking in space-aged accruements, but that is the case no more with the one-two navigation, phone, and touch-screen punch.

Looks
1. It’s hard to argue with classic. The styling of the Flying Spur has become the go-to look and so Bentley has remained true to the design first introduced eight years ago defined by a high and long roofline.

New for 2013
1. Not much here. The new Flying Spur will creep up on the market place in 2014, discreetly edging out its well-accomplished successor.

title: 2013 BMW 1-Series
subTitle: Although shorter in the bustle, it’s not short of bustle on the road.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 BMW 1-Series
promoTeaser: 2013 BMW 1-Series
metaTitle: 2013 BMW 1-Series Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW 1-Series Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Despite being thoroughly good and fun in every way, the rather costly 1-series presents a difficult choice: why not spend somewhat more on a 3-series model and get more car? The primary virtue of the 1-series is its tidy compactness on a rear-wheel-drive chassis that aims true. You get the same menu of engines and transmissions as in the 3-series, but the 1’s overall lighter weight makes for exhilarating performance. The trade-off is that the only models available are the coupe and convertible. Life with a two-door compact can be a struggle, as when you’re hurrying to expel passengers at the airport. (By then, they’ll be overjoyed to get out of the cramped back seat.) But if rear passengers would be a rarity and driving thrills are your pursuit, the 1-series offers its own rewards. The 128i comes with a 3.0-liter 230-horsepower six-cylinder and the choice of a six-speed manual or automatic transmission. The turbocharged 135i slightly revises the six to blast off with 300 horsepower; that six-speed manual is standard, but an enthusiastic driver might prefer the seven-speed dual-clutch automatic’s legerdemain. The 1-series sacrifices none of the BMW essentials, only a few inches here and there, and has a pug-like menace all its own.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors
1. Audi A3
2. BMW 3-series
3. Volvo C30

Cool Tech:
1. Aggressively geared seven-speed dual-clutch automatic gearbox with paddle shifters.
2. Fully automatic operation of convertible top.
3. Front fascia includes air curtains to counter wheel well turbulence, cutting aerodynamic drag.

Looks
1. If a black, white, or red body holds no appeal, spend $550 for any colors in the optional palette of metallic hues.
2. Rich red terra cotta Boston leather upholstery is available.
3. For drivers in weather-beaten states, the 135i--which comes standard with eighteen-inch wheels and performance tires--can be had with seventeen-inch wheels and all-season tires.

title: 2013 BMW 7-Series
subTitle: Revisions for 2013 make this agile and luxurious sedan more appealing than ever.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 BMW 7-Series
promoTeaser: 2013 BMW 7-Series
metaTitle: 2013 BMW 7-Series Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW 7-Series Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Never short on style or gadgetry, the 7-series is refreshed with some cool technology and a minor facelift that includes a new grille and larger air inlet for 2013. In the name of efficiency and fun, powertrains are revised for greater whoosh with less consumption. Now, for example, all engines work with an eight-speed automatic transmission. As before, the series offers a turbocharged six-cylinder in the 740i and long-wheelbase 740Li. This six is also included in the ActiveHybrid 7, whereas a V-8 had been offered. All 750 models, including those with all-wheel drive à la the 740Li, have turbo V-8s. Meanwhile, sitting on its throne, the range-topping 760Li could hardly be modest about its turbo V-12 producing 536 horsepower. On the tech side, LED headlights that produce a “natural daylight” type of high-contrast light are standard on the 760Li and optional on other models. The same 16-speaker Bang & Olufsen audio system that’s offered in the 6-series is available here, too. And the incorporation of 3-D into the navigation display makes the animation better and the displays more dynamic. The system also incorporates mobile-office functions with speech-to-text capability.  On top of everything else, the cruise control system all but steers the car in freeway traffic.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Mercedes-Benz S-Class
2. Audi A8
3. Jaguar XJ

Cool Tech:
1. To save fuel, auto start/stop on 740i/Li and 750i/Li kills the engine while you wait out red lights.
2. ActiveHybrid 7’s electric motor assists the six-cylinder upon strong demand for mid-range acceleration.
3. New navigation system includes 3-D and enhanced level of interactivity and includes voice-to-text funciton.

Looks:
1. Revised front apron features three-part air inlet with chrome bars.
2. New tail light lenses have different, more highly contrasting shades of red.
3. Redesigned front seats are sleeker.

New for 2013
1. Eight-speed automatic transmission is now included with all models.
2. The 9.2-inch screens for rear passengers appear to “float” on backs of front seats.
3. Bang & Olufsen Surround Sound System utilizes sixteen individually amplified speakers to create the acoustics of a reference listening room.

title: sedan
promoTeaserSmall: sedan
promoTeaser: sedan
metaTitle: sedan
metaDescription: sedan

pageElements.text: The traditional definition of a sedan is an enclosed passenger vehicle with two rows of seats. It’s an old idea, but it still works for most people and needs. If your car needs to hold five or fewer people, a good choice—compact to full-size—is probably here.

title: 2013 Buick Enclave
subTitle: A crossover with all the quiet competence and blend-in aesthetic you expect from the Buick nameplate.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Buick Enclave
promoTeaser: 2013 Buick Enclave
metaTitle: 2013 Buick Enclave Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Buick Enclave Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If a car is a fashion statement, the Buick Enclave is the polo shirt and pressed chinos of the automotive world—competent and a bit sedate. It’s also massively popular, with sales topping 57,000 in 2011, proving that the crossover is truly the new station wagon for the discerning family. Moderately restyled for 2013, the Enclave is offered in both front-wheel-drive and all-wheel-drive versions, and in Convenience, Leather, and Premium trim levels. All have a V-6 engine and six-speed automatic transmission that yield 24 mpg on the highway for the front-wheel-drive model. The four-wheel-drive model does slightly less, with 22 mpg on the highway. The three rows really do accommodate three rows of full-size passengers, but in consequence, there’s less luggage space in the back than might be desired, at a maximum of 23.3 cubic feet if you leave all rows of seats in place. Safety features include a front center side air bag, which Buick notes is an industry first, and a standard rear-vision camera. A power liftgate and remote start are both standard. Luxury add-ons abound, including a premium audio system, color-touch radio with DVD and navigation plus a seven-inch touchscreen, an eight-way passenger’s seat adjuster, and choccochino and cocoa leather color combinations for the interior.  The chrome accents are real, the stitching on the door trim and interior is real, and so is Buick’s commitment to the upscale family buyer.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Flex
2. Honda Pilot
3. Acura MDX

Cool Tech:
1. Front center side air bag—now every square inch of the front seat is protected, surely.

Looks:
1. Choccochino and cocoa leather color combinations.
2. Dual stainless steel exhaust.

New for 2013:
1. Mild makeover includes new hood, fenders, and grille plus lighting upgrades.
2. Interior gets a front center side air bag, Buick calling it industry first.
3. Revised suspension technology.

title: 2013 Infiniti IPL
subTitle: Infiniti shakes up the 2013 Infiniti Performance Line with the addition of a new IPL G Convertible.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Infiniti IPL
promoTeaser: 2013 Infiniti IPL
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti IPL Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti IPL here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Infiniti’s Performance Line jacks up the more prosaic G lineup with the 2013 IPL G Coupe and the addition of a new, four-passenger IPL G Convertible. The main gripe against the IPLs is that they are overpriced. The IPL G Convertible starts at $61,495, including an $895 destination charge, making it $8,600 more expensive than the base 2013 Infiniti G37 convertible. The IPL G Convertible is equipped with a 343-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6, seven-speed automatic transmission, IPL-tuned exhaust and suspension, nineteen-inch special wheels, and a three-piece retractable hardtop. Surprisingly, the exterior color choices on the new convertible are limited to just two: Malbec Black or Moonlight White. The droptop can be dolled up with extras like the $360 Midnight Black grille and $340 illuminated kick plates. A $545 rear wind deflector is a practical option, especially if you’re worried about your hair. Standard features include leather-trimmed seating and antilock brakes. The IPL G Coupe comes in two models, one with a seven-speed automatic transmission and another with a six-speed manual transmission. The IPL G Coupe gets a different look than its G sibling thanks to a different front and rear bumper design, sculpted side sills, a rear spoiler, and fancy nineteen-inch wheels. The pricing on the 2013 IPL G Convertible is designed to fall in between some of its toughest German competition. It is less expensive than the BMW M3 convertible, but more expensive than the Audi TTS roadster.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. BMW M3 Convertible
2. Audi TTS Roadster

New for 2013:
1. New IPL G Convertible.
2. Monaco Red interior now offered on G37 Coupe IPL 6MT models.

title: 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe
subTitle: The Hyundai Santa Fe gets a major redesign for 2013 and now comes in two flavors: a five-passenger model and a seven-passenger model that replaces the Hyundai Veracruz.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe
promoTeaser: 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Hyundai Santa Fe has been rejuvenated to appeal to families big and small who want a crossover vehicle. The Santa Fe now comes in a five-passenger Sport version and a larger, three-row, seven-passenger model that replaces the Hyundai Veracruz. The bigger Santa Fe won’t be available until January. The Santa Fe went on a major diet and shed 266 pounds versus the outgoing model. The result is a big improvement in fuel economy, with the base Sport model returning 33 mpg on the highway. Two engine choices are available in the Sport model: a 190 horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder GDI engine and a 264-horsepower turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder GDI engine. The larger Santa Fe gets the 290-horsepower 3.3-liter GDI V-6 engine. All engines are linked to a six-speed transmission. The Korean crossover is available with front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive. The 2013 Santa Fe has a more sculpted look and standard chrome exterior touches. Families will appreciate the flexible seating arrangements and the attention to safety features, including seven standard air bags. There are lots more extras, too, including such options as a panoramic sunroof, push-button start, heated steering wheel, and a second-row seat that slides. The Santa Fe used to be priced more attractively than the competition, but that may no longer be the case. The 2013 Santa Fe gets a significant price increase versus the 2012 model, courtesy of all the upgrades.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Explorer
2. Chevrolet Equinox
3. Nissan Pathfinder
4. Toyota Highlander

Cool Tech:
1. New Driver Selectable Steering Mode, which lets the driver pick three operating modes – comfort, normal, and sport -- depending on driving preferences and road conditions. (Unusual in this segment)
2. Hyundai’s first application of Active Cornering Control all-wheel drive, a system that can anticipate traction needs and deliver additional stability through braking.

New for 2013:
1. All-new crossover architecture.
2. Two-model strategy with five-passenger and seven-passenger models.
3. New exterior look.

title: 2013 Hyundai Sonata
subTitle: The 2013 Hyundai Sonata is the Korean automaker’s highly regarded bread-and-butter family sedan that is gearing up to do major battle in the midsize sedan segment.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Hyundai Sonata
promoTeaser: 2013 Hyundai Sonata
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Sonata Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Hyundai Sonata here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The sleek 2013 Hyundai Sonata is a carryover model with a few improvements, including the addition of heated seats as standard equipment to all models and packages except the base GLS model. The Sonata, which had a major redesign two years ago, is widely regarded as a world-class effort and a worthy competitor to the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord. But the segment is more competitive than ever this year, with the redesigned 2013 Ford Fusion and 2013 Nissan Altima vying for attention from consumers. Hyundai eliminated the base Sonata GLS with a six-speed manual transmission from the 2013 Sonata lineup. The base sedan now is equipped with a 200-horsepower 2.4-liter GDI four-cylinder engine linked to a six-speed automatic transmission. The base Sonata also gets a $1,100 price increase over the outgoing base model. The uplevel Sonata Limited gets a 274-horsepower 2.0-liter turbocharged GDI four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission. The 2013 Sonata with the 2.4-liter inline four-cylinder engine gets a respectable 35 mpg highway rating, according to the EPA. The Sonata can be transformed from a family hauler to a near-luxury car with the addition of such options as a $2,900 Limited Premium package that includes a panoramic sunroof, navigation system, rear back-up camera, and Infinity premium speakers and stereo components. The 2013 Sonata comes standard with three months of XM Satellite Radio. Every 2013 Sonata has electronic stability control as standard equipment.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Fusion
2. Toyota Camry
3. Honda Accord
4. Nissan Altima

Cool Tech:
1. One of the few midsize sedans to offer digital HD Radio Technology from the factory.
2. Hyundai Blue Link telematics system is the Korean answer to OnStar and Sync. Has “Geo Fence” feature that sends you an email if car goes over a set speed limit (designed for parents to keep track of kids).

New for 2013:
1. Heated seats added as standard equipment to all models and packages except base GLS model.
2. Sunroof choices expanded for Sonata Limited.

title: 2013 Infiniti M/M Hybrid
subTitle: The 2013 Infiniti M performance luxury sedan is designed to give Nissan’s upscale brand a foothold in a segment dominated by Mercedes-Benz and BMW.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Infiniti M/M Hybrid
promoTeaser: 2013 Infiniti M/M Hybrid
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti M/M Hybrid Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti M/M Hybrid here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Infiniti M performance luxury sedan is designed to give Nissan’s upscale brand a foothold in a segment dominated by Mercedes-Benz and BMW. However, that foothold may be shod with an L.L. Bean utility boot instead of a sexy Jimmy Choo. The M sedan gets a bulging, strapping exterior that gives few clues to the car’s elegant interior. So top drawer is the cabin of the M that it can be ordered with a special Japanese ash wood trim with genuine silver embedded in the grain. Of course, the trim is part of a $4,200 premium package. Such packages can raise the price of the M well past the $50,000 mark rapidly. A base M37 starts at $49,095, including an $895 destination charge. There are three engine choices: a 330-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6, a 360-horsepower hybrid V-6, and a 420-horsepower 5.6-liter V-6. The hybrid version is fast and frugal, returning 27 mpg in city and 32 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. A seven-speed automatic transmission is standard on all models. All-wheel drive is available. The 2013 M lineup gets a serious boost of sportiness, with the popular sport package offered for the first time with Infiniti M AWD models and a new performance tire-and-wheel package with twenty-inch wheels and tires and sport brakes that replaces the previous eighteen-inch wheel package.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. BMW 5 Series
2. Jaguar XF
3. Lexus GS
4. Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Infiniti’s “Forest Air” climate system that uses an electronic air purifier to control odor and humidity. It also doesn’t “blow” air, but uses a “gentle breeze.”

New for 2013:
1. Sport package offered for first time with Infiniti M AWD models.
2. Premium package now includes rear sonar system and Infiniti Connection.
3. New Stone Sport interior color with Sport models.
4. New performance tire-and-wheel package with twenty-inch wheels and tires and sport brakes replaces the previous eighteen-inch wheel package.

title: 2013 Cadillac Escalade EXT
subTitle: Don’t let its Cadillac appearance fool you; the pickup member of the Escalade family does have a workable, although small, truck bed
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Cadillac Escalade EXT
promoTeaser: 2013 Cadillac Escalade EXT
metaTitle: 2013 Cadillac Escalade EXT Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Cadillac Escalade EXT Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If you absolutely can’t make up your mind whether to get a luxury vehicle or a pickup truck, here’s your answer. The Cadillac Escalade EXT is fancy yet reasonably practical, with seating for five thanks to a rear bench seat. You wouldn’t get the Escalade EXT for serious ongoing hauling needs, since its truck bed is only five feet long, but it comes with GM’s clever Midgate system, also used on the Chevrolet Avalanche. The Midgate lets you fold the rear seats down and extend the pickup bed inside the cabin, giving you a much more useful eight-foot bed. You can also unlatch the rear window and store it inside a recess in the Midgate panel for open-air driving enjoyment. Features and goodies are extensive and include Bose audio, leather-trimmed heated and cooled front seats, and dual-zone climate control. There’s also a standard lockable tonneau cover—although you can take it off to increase storage versatility. Since this is, after all, a sport-utility vehicle turned into a pickup, it shares the same V-8 engine and six-speed automatic transmission as the other Escalades. The Escalade’s all-wheel drive and 7,600-pound towing capacity mean it’s more than just a good-looking luxury vehicle—it’s one you can actually get some utility from.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Ford F-150 Platinum
2. GMC Sierra Denali
3. Ram 1500 Laramie Longhorn

Cool Tech:
1. Midgate to expand cargo area from five to eight feet, supplementing short truck bed.
2. Optional inclination sensor goes off if the system senses vehicle being towed, jacked up, or flatbedded (as in the case of being stolen).

Looks:
1. Twenty-two-inch chrome aluminum wheels on EXT Premium.

New for 2013
1. Enhanced navigation system.

title: 2013 Cadillac XTS
subTitle: Cadillac’s brand-new XTS offers all the interior luxury and technology you could ask from an American luxury car
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Cadillac XTS
promoTeaser: 2013 Cadillac XTS
metaTitle: 2013 Cadillac XTS Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Cadillac XTS Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Cadillac’s desire to win shoppers over (or back) to its brand, away from German luxury sedans, is well known—and understandable. This new car should help with that. No, the all-new XTS is not a high-performance car—look to Cadillac’s other new model, the ATS, for that—but it still should appeal to many import buyers as well as to the older demographic that Cadillac has long attracted. Why? Because it is straight up hedonistic, with a gorgeously luxuriant interior and a smooth ride in the best large-sedan manner. The feeling starts with Cadillac’s new Cue information and entertainment system, making its debut on the 2013 XTS. Its eight-inch touchscreen incorporates the capacitive touch of an iPhone for a satisfyingly intuitive user experience.  It continues with the Bose audio, leather trim choices all the way up to a buttery full leather interior depending on model, subtle accent lighting, and real wood trim. The XTS is a front-wheel drive car, in contrast to the ATS, and all-wheel drive is available. Its safety systems are as thoroughly indulgent as its luxury equipment. For example, there’s an optional Driver Assistance active safety package that incorporates active short-range radar and a smart camera above the inside mirror that shoots twelve high-definition photos per minute, all in the service of spotting and avoiding hazards. Performance purists may dislike the fact that the XTS has front-wheel drive, but this is probably not the product they’re looking for anyway.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi A6
2. Lincoln MKS
3. Mercedes-Benz E350
4. BMW 5 Series

Cool Tech:
1. Sensor Fusion safety system uses active short-range radar and smart camera to spot and avoid unexpected hazards.
2. Cue information and entertainment system.

Looks
1. Platinum edition is Full Monty of luxury with Opus full leather seats, heated and cooled seats, power rear window shade, fourteen-speaker Bose system, leather-wrapped trim and console, suede headliner, etc., etc.
2. Apple iPad handed out with each XTS.

title: 2013 Kia Soul
subTitle: Kia’s square compact is still rocking, thanks to a few tweaks for the 2013 model year.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Kia Soul
promoTeaser: 2013 Kia Soul
metaTitle: 2013 Kia Soul Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Kia Soul here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Thanks to the memorable Kia Soul ad starring the rapping hamsters singing LMFAO’s “Party Rock Anthem,” the square compact is firmly embedded in the popular culture. The Soul gets only a few tweaks for 2013, including power folding outside mirrors standard on the Exclaim model, several new exterior colors, and Bluetooth with steering-wheel mounted audio controls standard on the base manual transmission model. The Soul competes well against other boxy cars, including the Nissan Cube and Scion xB. Soul offers good value for the money, impressive safety features, nice cabin quality, and solid brakes. Buyers can opt for the 138-horsepower 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine or a 164-horsepower four-cylinder engine linked to either a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. While it returns decent fuel economy, the Soul falls just short of the 40-mpg Holy Grail. The 1.6-liter model with a six-speed automatic transmission returns 27 mpg in city driving and 35 mpg on the highway. A Soul Eco model with Intelligent Stop and Go technology and an Active Eco system wrings out a bit more fuel economy, returning 29 mpg city and 36 mpg highway. The Eco package is available with either engine. There’s no denying the fun quotient with Soul, even for thrifty-minded buyers. An optional sound system has backlit speakers that can flash in time with the music.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Nissan Cube
2. Scion xB
3. Scion xD

Cool Tech:
1. Intelligent Stop and Go technology and an Active Eco system for fuel-efficient driving.
2. Lights in the door-mounted speakers that flash in time with the music.

New for 2013:
1. Dark chrome accent ring around grille.
2. Bluetooth with steering-wheel mounted audio controls standard on base manual transmission model.
3. Power folding outside mirrors standard for Exclaim.
4. Clear white exterior color optional for Exclaim.
5. Dune exterior color available for Plus.
6. Molten, Titanium and Moss exterior color available for base model.

title: 2013 Kia Sportage
subTitle: The Kia Sportage, a compact sport-ute with a techie edge, got a major redesign two years ago and receives only modest upgrades for the new model year.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Kia Sportage
promoTeaser: 2013 Kia Sportage
metaTitle: 2013 Kia Sportage Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Kia Sportage here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Kia Sportage is a realistic alternative to other small crossovers in the market, including the Honda CR-V and Ford Escape. It stands out with its sharp styling, powerful engine in SX trim, lengthy warranty, and intuitive controls. Although the Sportage is a sibling to the Hyundai Tucson, it gets a unique look inside and out. One downside: the Sportage has less cargo capacity than some of its key competitors. The Sportage got a major redesign two years ago and receives only modest upgrades for the new model year. They include standard power folding outside mirrors, a new blue interior package for the EX model with dark blue cloth seats and a black headliner, standard LED accent lights for the LX and EX models, and a standard sun visor extender on all models. The base Sportage gets a 176-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine with a six-speed manual or automatic transmission. A standard 260-horsepower 2.0-liter turbocharged gasoline direct injection four-cylinder engine revs up the Sportage SX. While the base Sportage returns 22 mpg in city driving and 32 mpg on the highway, performance enthusiasts won’t pay too great a penalty if they opt for the turbo engine. The EPA says it returns 22 mpg in city driving and 29 mpg on the highway. The Sportage comes in either front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Escape
2. Honda CR-V
3. Hyundai Tucson
4. Mitsubishi Outlander Sport

Cool Tech:
1. EX trim levels come with active EcoMinder indicator for fuel-efficient driving.
2. SX trim gets voice-activated navigation system with SiriusXM Traffic data.

New for 2013:
1. LED accent lights standard for LX and EX models.
2. LED daytime running lights exclusive to SX model.
3. Standard power folding outside mirrors.
4. Blue interior package for EX model.
5. Sun visor extender standard on all models.

title: 2013 Ferrari California
subTitle: The Ferrari California was designed to come in first as it brings the hardtop convertible and the V-8 to the market
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ferrari California
promoTeaser: 2013 Ferrari California
metaTitle: 2013 Ferrari California Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Ferrari California Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: If you’re a better driver than your boyfriend, you’ll find joy driving as a California girl. The California is the only Ferrari that’s made with a mid-mounted V-8. It once was the lineup’s only hard-topped convertible until the Ferrari 458 Spider came along and shook up the lineup. This means the California is a bit more tame and rigid, but still sophisticated. It was designed to be easy to drive off the rack; no need for complicated engine configurations. The California is about the experience of driving a Ferrari, not the technical aspects of how it’s done.  The rear accommodates the hard top, so the proportions are not quite as sleek as the other cars in the stellar Ferrari lineup. So here we have all you need – a straightforward Ferrari named after a Ferrari nameplate that is four decades old.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Aston Martin V-8 Vantage
2. Lamborghini Gallardo
3. Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG

Cool Tech:
1. A new infotainment system using a 6.5 inch touch screen display.
2. The seat adjustments are varied and tailored to hug the body.

Looks
1. The California has a distinct bodyline that draws from the 1957 California 250.
2. The California is available with a bench for storage and it includes a fold-down rear seat.

New for 2013
1. The suspension is stiffer and therefore more fun to drive fast.
2. The California was the Ferrari to include a manual transmission, and now the manual is no more.

title: 2013 Ferrari FF
subTitle: The Ferrari FF: that's four-seater with four-wheel drive.
promoTeaserSmall: The Ferrari FF: that's four-seater with four-wheel drive.
promoTeaser: The Ferrari FF: that's four-seater with four-wheel drive.
metaTitle: 2013 Ferrari FF Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Ferrari FF Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Your ears aren’t ringing from the sound of that wicked V-12 engine. That’s right, the Ferrari FF is a hatchback that has four seats. That’s what the FF stands for — Ferrari Four. It has all-wheel drive, another first for the Italian automaker, which means that you could theoretically drive the FF in a snowstorm. You can pick up your car seat kid in the first Ferrari grocery-getter ever, and there’s even room for soccer equipment and golf clubs in the generous storage area. Front airbags, traction and stability control are standard. Obviously, Ferrari is doing a lot here. The FF is no slouch and is still priced like a Ferrari at $320,000 and it drives like one, too, so you can cause trouble driving this bad boy. "FF" could also stand for Ferrari Fast.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Porsche Panamera Turbo S
2. Aston Martin Rapide

Cool Tech:
1. A new rear-seat infotainment system.
2. Two screens are positioned in the backseat for television and DVD viewing.
3. The FF features a 1,280-watt, sixteen-channel stereo to blast the tunes in surround sound.

Looks
1. The Ferrari manages to incorporate the 458’s headlight design.
2. The dramatic design is reminiscent of the Batmobile.

title: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid
subTitle: Ford tosses down the hybrid gauntlet with its new model, which gets 47 miles per gallon both in town and on the highway
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid
promoTeaser: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid
metaTitle: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Ford C-Max Hybrid Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Hybrids are settling into the mainstream. The proof comes from Ford’s all-new C-Max Hybrid and Energi. The compact car is cute in the current Ford style, with wedgy shaping and a toothy grille, but its main selling point is fuel economy. It is rated at 47 mpg both in town and on the highway—which Ford hastens to point out is 7 mpg better than the Toyota Prius v’s highway numbers. The C-Max has a lithium-ion battery that recharges when the gasoline engine is in use; plus, there’s regenerative braking—recycling at its least onerous—which recaptures up to 95 percent of the energy used in braking and uses it to recharge the battery. The C-Max is not only efficient; it also responds to the eco-conscious aesthetic by using a greenery theme in its Smartgauge display, which displays more leaves and vines as a “visual reward” when a driver is more efficient in his or her driving habits. The C-Max’s popular price, starting just over $25,000—lower than its closest rival, the Toyota Prius, and some $10,000 cheaper than the Chevrolet Volt and the Nissan Leaf—will help it win fans, as will its uncontroversial styling. The fact that you can drive the plug-in Energi at speeds up to 85 mph on electrical power alone should electrify the highway commuter crowd. But the number-one drawing card will be its efficiency in a time of insecure gasoline prices.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Toyota Prius v
2. Toyota Prius III

Cool Tech:
1. Smartgauge display shows a leafy vine that gets lusher the more efficiently the car is driven.
2. Regenerative braking and Brake Coach to help get the most out of it.
3. ECO Cruise highway cruise control technology.

Looks:
1. In-floor storage in second row.

New for 2013
1. All-new model.

title: First Car
promoTeaserSmall: First Car
promoTeaser: First Car
metaTitle: First Car
metaDescription: First Car

pageElements.text: We define First Car material as a car priced right—close to or under $20,000—for someone just starting out. Ideally it’s also compact, fuel efficient, a safety leader, and equally well suited for an empty nester or just about anyone on a serious budget.

title: indulgence
promoTeaserSmall: indulgence
promoTeaser: indulgence
metaTitle: indulgence
metaDescription: indulgence

pageElements.text: If this is the kind of car you imagine being followed by paparazzi, or parked outside the casino at Monte Carlo, it fits into our Indulgence category. Perhaps you are in a position to buy one of these. Congrats! For the rest of us, it’s always OK to look.

title: 2013 Porsche 911
subTitle: The latest version of this archetypal sports car is joined by two all-wheel-drive models.
promoTeaserSmall: The latest version of this archetypal sports car is joined by two all-wheel-drive models.
promoTeaser: The latest version of this archetypal sports car is joined by two all-wheel-drive models.
metaTitle: 2013 Porsche 911 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the Porsche 911 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 911 was renewed for 2013, gaining many things while losing others. With a vigorous stance and large wheels and tires, it gains a distinctly new appearance. It also gains a high-tech center console and optional eighteen-way power seats. It loses weight while gaining efficiency, and coupe models gain a sliding glass sunroof. So far, you’ve only counted positives, right? Well, consider that the new, electrically-assisted power steering wins few praises, and the longer wheelbase contributes to a slightly less immediate driving experience. Now the 911 Carrera 4 and 4S all-wheel-drive models, each available as coupe or convertible, have joined the lineup with the rear-drive Carrera (350-horsepower 3.4-liter flat six-cylinder) and Carrera S. With the S, they share the same 400-horsepower 3.8-liter flat six and seven-speed manual or optional seven-speed dual-clutch automatic gearbox, but the all-wheel drive cars are about two inches wider in back to accommodate different hardware and slightly fatter tires. The 4 and 4S introduce active cruise control and crash avoidance systems. If you need something with a top speed as high as 196 mph, the 500-horsepower 911 Turbo and 530-horsepower 911 Turbo S coupe and convertible, based on the previous-generation car, remain on sale.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Corvette
2. Jaguar XK
3. Nissan GT-R

Cool Tech Items:
1. Carrera 4 and 4S feature an instrument-panel display that shows how the engine’s output is distributed.
2. The world’s first seven-speed manual transmission is the standard offering.
3. Convertible top’s four cloth-covered magnesium panels easily fold away.

Looks:
1. Carrera 4 and 4S have a new red light band that connects the two tail lights.
2. Special available colors include lime gold metallic, a $3,140 option and ethereal as all get-out.
3. Aluminum, wood, or leather trim for the interior: you choose.

New for 2013:
1. Carrera 4 and 4S introduce adaptive cruise control to the 911 lineup.
2. Porsche Active Safe is available with automatic transmission models as a means of preventing front-end collisions.
3. With the Sport Chrono pack in Sport Plus mode, this transmission automatically double-clutches for you during downshifts.

title: 2013 Porsche Boxster
subTitle: It’s a question of balance, and the Boxster’s answers are right on the beam.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Porsche Boxster
promoTeaser: 2013 Porsche Boxster
metaTitle: 2013 Porsche Boxster Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Porsche Boxster with complete specifications and buying information! It's all on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: While the Boxster is all-new for 2013, it drives like the old car, so everyone breathes a sigh of relief. They didn’t mess it up! While looking similar to its precursor, it benefits from a subtle redefinition that makes the bodywork even more handsome and the shape more evocative. (And it looks less like the Porsche 911 than before.) An array of striking exterior colors and bold, or even shocking, interior upholstery combinations can be summoned as a way of making your Boxster extra special. There are even three different steering wheels among your choices. The Boxster now has a 265-horsepower 2.7-liter flat six-cylinder while the Boxster S has a 315-horsepower 3.4-liter flat six. A six-speed manual gearbox is standard with the seven-speed dual-clutch automatic optional. The latter transmission is faster actin’ than Tinactin. As a fuel-saving ploy, the new “coasting” mode decouples the engine from the wheels when the car is coasting, thereby reducing friction. But when the driver is in a fractious frame of mind and seeks unruliness, the available Sport Chrono feature manages all onboard systems and helps the car achieve its highest performance. So equipped, the S will sprint from 0 to 60 mph in just 4.7 seconds.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competitors:
1. Nissan 370Z
2. BMW Z4
3. Audi TT

Cool Tech Items:
1. LED position lights and daytime running lamps are included.
2. Recaptured energy from the brakes recharges the battery.
3. Dynamic transmission mounts reduce drivetrain vibration.

Looks:
1. A lime gold metallic body with agate gray and lime gold leather upholstery would give a lovely glow in the dark.
2. Choose from among three steering wheels: sports, multifunction, or the high-tech Sport Design.
3. Twenty-inch wheels are available.

New for 2013:
1. “Coasting” mode allows the car to maximize efficiency.
2. The Boxster’s stance is accentuated by standard eighteen-inch wheels.
3. Highway fuel economy increases to 30 mpg with the manual transmission.

title: 2013 Honda Crosstour
subTitle: An unusual car with a little something for everyone
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Honda Crosstour
promoTeaser: 2013 Honda Crosstour
metaTitle: 2013 Honda Crosstour Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Honda Crosstour Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Crosstour is easily Honda’s most distinctive mid-size car, with a body more SUV-like than the studiously sedan-y Accord and Civic. The 2013 model year will bring an even more aggressive style, inching it closer to the SUV side of the crossover market. The Crosstour shares much of what’s inside with the Accord, including the engine and suspension. It also makes use of variable cylinder management, which allows the car to adjust its power to the demands of the driver and increases fuel economy. The 2013 model will come with Honda’s new safety equipment, including blind spot cameras, lane departure warning, and front collision warning. The Crosstour distinguishes itself from Honda’s other mid-size cars not only in its styling, but with its much greater capacity. With 25.7 cubic feet of cargo space, it has just about twice as much space as the Accord or Civic. Despite being one of only four Honda models not rated above 30 mpg on the highway, it still gets a relatively strong 25 to 27 mpg highway and 17 to 18 mpg in the city, enough to incite gas-pump envy from plenty of drivers.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competition:
1. Acura TSX
2. Subaru Outback
3. Volvo XC70

Cool Tech:
1. USB audio interface and auxiliary input jack.
2. Honda’s newest collision warning safety technology.

Looks:
1. Aggressive, SUV reminiscent styling.
2. Leather-trimmed interior, available in cream and black.
3. Colored ambient lighting on console.

New for 2013:
1. New powertrain options.
2. State of the art safety technology.

title: 2013 Hyundai Accent
subTitle: The base 2013 Hyundai Accent gets a major price bump for the new model year -- but more standard equipment.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Hyundai Accent
promoTeaser: 2013 Hyundai Accent
metaTitle: 2013 Hyundai Accent Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Hyundai Accent Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Hyundai Accent used to be one of the value leaders in the small-car segment, but the Korean automaker is taking its Ford Fiesta fighter upmarket for 2013. The base 2013 Accent gets a $2,000 price increase over the outgoing base 2012 Accent GLS ­ but Hyundai has beefed up the standard equipment list considerably. Standard features now include air-conditioning, remote keyless entry, an audio system with six speakers, heated side mirrors, body-colored door handles, and a sunglasses holder. The Accent even gets a new, optional power sunroof on the SE model. But shoppers should be aware that the base Accent is now more expensive than several of its key competitors, including the base 2013 Ford Fiesta S sedan. The Accent is a mighty performer and won’t disappoint at the pump. It is equipped with a 138-horsepower 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine linked to either an optional six-speed automatic transmission or standard six-speed manual transmission. The EPA says that either powertrain configuration will return 30 mpg in city driving and 40 mpg on the highway. Much of Accent’s competition does not hit that magic 40 mpg mark. Six air bags are standard on the Accent and there’s no skimping on styling, thanks to Accent’s newer sculptured look. Five-door Accent SE models get a sporty roof-mounted spoiler and vertical taillights, dressing up the subcompact even more.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Ford Fiesta
2. Nissan Versa
3. Chevrolet Sonic

Cool Tech:
1. Active ECO system modifies engine and transmission control to smooth out throttle response, resulting in a seven percent increase in fuel economy, according to Hyundai.

New for 2013:
1. Heated side mirrors are new for 2013 and are standard on all trim levels.
2. New optional power sunroof on Accent SE trim.
3. More standard equipment than outgoing 2012 model, including air conditioning, audio system with six speakers and a sunglasses holder.

title: 2013 Volkswagen Touareg
subTitle: Volkswagen’s answer to a luxury SUV.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Volkswagen Touareg
promoTeaser: 2013 Volkswagen Touareg
metaTitle: 2013 Volkswagen Touareg Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Volkswagen Touareg here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Touareg is billed as a crossover, but it behaves much more like an SUV. With a powerful V-6 engine, eight-speed automatic transmission, a tow rating of 7,700 pounds, and a massive cargo hold, the only thing that holds it in the crossover category is the lack of a third row. Volkswagen almost makes up for this with the large cargo area and a rear seat that splits three ways for convenient folding, but the fact is that if you absolutely need a seven-seater, the Touareg won’t do the trick. The Touareg is far and away Volkswagen’s most expensive car, with a price range topping $60,000. The car is also far and away Volkswagen’s most luxurious offering, with walnut wood accents, available leather seats, and various available sound systems that will blast your eardrums into submission. The fuel economy is decent for a car this size, especially if you choose the diesel engine or the V-6 hybrid. If you’re more concerned with brand cachet than quality or functionality, you should spring for an Audi or a BMW. But lacking a luxury brand badge doesn’t make the Touareg any less of a car, and it is certainly Volkswagen’s best option for SUV-seekers.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Chevrolet Traverse
2. Ford Explorer
3. Honda Pilot

Cool Tech:
1. Available eight-inch navigation system with color touch screen.
2. Standard Bluetooth and iPod connectivity.
3. Standard 115-volt outlet.

Looks:
1. Big, bold SUV design.
2. Comfortable, spacious layout.
3. Available panoramic sunroof.

New for 2013:
1. TDI model goes from 225 to 240 horsepower.
2. New LED taillights for Hybrid.
3. Available wood-grain trim in high-end models.

title: 2013 Volkswagen Tiguan
subTitle: Half tiger, half iguana, half really convenient
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Volkswagen Tiguan
promoTeaser: 2013 Volkswagen Tiguan
metaTitle: 2013 Volkswagen Tiguan Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Volkswagen Tiguan here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Many Volkswagens have quirky names, but the Tiguan takes the cake for originality. The name is a portmanteau of “tiger” and “iguana.” It is unclear specifically which iguana-like qualities Volkswagen hopes to embody in the Tiguan, but for a car this utile, we’ll give the name a pass. Conceived as a larger alternative to the Golf , the Tiguan has space for five and can tow up to 2,200 pounds. The cargo hold is large, especially with rear seats down. The Tiguan a prime example of a crossover, combining true versatility with a powerful, turbocharged engine and a smooth ride. Missing from the Tiguan is good gas mileage. It doesn’t quite make the 30-mpg mark, one of only three Volkswagens to miss that milestone. The controls are familiar and easy to use, and the interior is equally user-friendly. Each seat in the back row folds separately, so you could fold down one, two, or all three to accommodate anything from skis to flea market finds. There is an available panoramic sunroof, touchscreen, and six-disc CD changer with MP3 hookup and SD card input. With all your photos and music stored in the dash, you may not mind playing chauffer to the kids.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Ford Escape
2. Honda CR-V
3. Nissan Rogue

Cool Tech:
1. Standard Bluetooth connectivity and auxiliary input.
2. Available iPod cable and Sirius XM radio.
3. Available keyless entry and push-button start.

Looks:
1. Available power panoramic sunroof.
2. 40/40/20 split rear folding seats.
3. Large, easily readable dashboard and controls.

New for 2013:
1. Standard electronic parking break.
2. Standard leather-wrapped steering wheel.
3. New rearview camera for SEL trim.

title: 2013 Jeep Compass
subTitle: A Jeep built for the concrete jungle
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Jeep Compass
promoTeaser: 2013 Jeep Compass
metaTitle: 2013 Jeep Compass Buyer's Guide - Jean Know Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Jeep Compass Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Jeep Compass is the least Jeep-y car offered by the brand. It looks smoother and more refined than other models, but despite what Jeep’s marketing team says, it is not designed for off-roading the way many of its siblings are. That said, it is more than adequate for drives around town, especially if you need space in the trunk for groceries or sports gear. The Compass gets decent gas mileage, reaching 30 miles to the gallon on the highway. The interior is where the Compass shines, with attractive bucket seats and standard chrome accents. A navigation system is available, as is phone connectivity. The standard media outfit includes an MP3 jack and Sirius satellite radio is an option. If you’re really determined to take this little Jeep off-roading, an available package will outfit the Compass with All Terrain Tires, tow hooks, and other upgrades that will make a trip to the back country more feasible. Jeep has foretold the demise of the Compass and its sibling the Patriot, to be replaced with a new, small SUV likely based on a Fiat. That car won’t show up until 2013, but if you can’t bring yourself to wait that long, the Compass will still do the trick.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competition:
1. Kia Sportage
2. Mitsubishi Outlander Sport
3. Suzuki SX4

Cool Tech:
1. Available off-roading package with hill-start assist and descent control.
2. Available Uconnect infotainment system.
3. Available media center with forty-gigabyte hard drive.

Looks:
1. Less aggressive grille than other Jeeps.
2. Borrows design cues from Grand Cherokee.
3. Available power sunroof.

New for 2013:
1. New 2.0-liter engine with manual transmission.
2. Two new exterior colors.

title: 2013 Jeep Grand Cherokee
subTitle: An off-roader that keeps you comfortable
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Jeep Grand Cherokee
promoTeaser: 2013 Jeep Grand Cherokee
metaTitle: 2013 Jeep Grand Cherokee Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Jeep Grand Cherokee Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Grand Cherokee is Jeep’s star automobile, with the highest base price range and most extensive options of any car in the brand. It is also the most powerful Jeep ever, with a Hemi V-8 engine in the SRT8 model that is so fun you won’t want to park it. The Grand Cherokee is more than capable off-road with various drive and suspension settings to fit the demands of the trail. Better yet, the Grand Cherokee has retained its ability to drive the back roads without skimping on the interior. With four different trim levels and the SRT8 model, interior choices range from just plain comfortable to quite luxurious, with the top of the line Grand Cherokee boasting leather bucket seats and wood accents throughout the cabin. An optional navigation system includes voice recognition and Sirius Real Time Traffic information so you can skirt the crowds on your way out of town. If this Jeep sounds too good to be true, the fuel economy should sober you up. The Grand Cherokee barely tops 20 miles to the gallon on the highway, and claims the lowest mileage of Jeep’s fleet quite easily.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Ford Explorer
2. Honda Pilot
3. Nissan Pathfinder

Cool Tech:
1. Optional navigation system with voice recognition.
2. Varying drive and suspension options for off-roading.
3. Hemi V-8 can tow 7,400 pounds.

Looks:
1. Available panoramic sunroof.
2. Upscale interior.
3. Available rear entertainment center and DVD player.

New for 2013:
1. Two special SRT8 models, Alpine and Vapor.

title: 2013 Jeep Wrangler
subTitle: Jeep’s enviable off-roader
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Jeep Wrangler
promoTeaser: 2013 Jeep Wrangler
metaTitle: 2013 Jeep Wrangler Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Jeep Wrangler Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Jeep Wrangler is one of the most recognizable SUVs on the market, and its adventurous attitude is as impossible to ignore as its bold styling. The consummate Jeep, the Wrangler promises to take you anywhere you want to go, even if where you want to go is deep into the wilderness. A series of design changes in recent years have made the Wrangler more comfortable for daily use. New seats offer more support for long drives and a new soft top is easier for one person to put on and take off. The Wrangler’s V-6 engine is more than capable of powering this large car, though the Wrangler’s off-road chops can make it feel clunky on paved roads. Standard removable doors will please thrill seekers, and an optional navigation system with DVD/CD player and MP3 capability will please the more comfort-minded. The six available trim levels mean that there are plenty of options, but even the priciest Wrangler still comes in under $40,000. The bottom line is: no matter who you are or what you do, the Wrangler will make you feel like you’re on an adventure.
Fun-O-meter: 8

Competition:
1. Nissan Xterra
2. Suzuki Grand Vitara
3. Toyota FJ Cruiser

Cool Tech:
1. Removable doors.
2. Available navigation system with MP3 capability.
3. Extremely capable off-road.

Looks:
1. Nine exterior color choices.
2. New front seats for added comfort.
3. Available with body-color three-piece hard top.

New for 2013:
1. Six new exterior colors.
2. Refreshed design on wheels, interior lighting.
3. New soft top easier to manipulate.

title: 2012 Lamborghini Gallardo
subTitle: Just what you need to get your blood pumping
promoTeaserSmall: 2012 Lamborghini Gallardo
promoTeaser: 2012 Lamborghini Gallardo
metaTitle: 2012 Lamborghini Gallardo Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Lamborghini Gallardo Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Lamborghini Gallardo is a study in relativism. The less expensive of the two Lambos on the market, it comes around $200,000, roughly the price of a starter home in a nice neighborhood. Slower and far subtler than the Lamborghini Aventador, it still tops out just above 200 mph and has unmistakable supercar looks. In a machine like this, everything comes second to power. The Gallardo doesn’t disappoint, offering a choice of a 550-, 560-, or 570-horsepower engine. The 570-horse version takes the Gallardo from 0 to 62 mph in less than four seconds and 0 to 124 mph in about 10 seconds. Some models are available with all-wheel drive to help keep control of the car at high speeds. The Gallardo seats two, and is available as a convertible with a soft top. Compared to its stunning performance, the interior is rarely the selling point on a Lamborghini, but that doesn’t mean it falls short. With leather seats, available two-tone or monotone, available accents like a suede steering wheel, and an available navigation system (albeit, a very expensive one), you will be plenty comfortable while zooming past plebs in their sedans.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competition:
1. Audi R8 GT
2. Ferrari 458 Italia
3. McLaren MP4-12C

Cool Tech:
1. Extreme speed, hugely powerful engines.
2. Available Navigation system with satellite radio.
3. Available all-wheel drive.

Looks:
1. Eyecatching Lamborghini design.
2. Leather interior available in two-tone.
3. Available as soft top convertible.

title: 2013 Suzuki Grand Vitara
subTitle: For on- or off-roading adventures, the Grand Vitara is your go-to car
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Suzuki Grand Vitara
promoTeaser: 2013 Suzuki Grand Vitara
metaTitle: 2013 Suzuki Grand Vitara Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Suzuki Grand Vitara here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: If your definition of fun involves off-roading and adventure, but Jeeps aren’t really your cup of tea, Suzuki’s Grand Vitara may be of interest to you. The Grand Vitara is a great blend of on-road comfort and off-road capability, making it a car that you can use for work or play. If you’re concerned about the wear and tear this car can take, don’t worry too much. You should always take car of your vehicle, but know that the Grand Vitara does have a reinforced inner-framework similar to ones found in pricier trucks and SUVs. Most of the car’s trim levels come standard with automatic transmission, but a five-speed manual transmission is also available. The Grand Vitara doesn’t come in a wide array of colors unlike its competitor over at Honda, but it does come with a variety of features that come standard on the base model. Not only do you get the expected power windows, keyless entry, digital clock, and air conditioning, the base model comes standard with touchscreen navigation; if you upgrade to the Premium or Limited level, you’ll have access to hands-free calling and nüLink! Services, which gives you access to two- and three-dimensional maps, speed limits, movie listings, and parking locations so you never have to fumble with printed maps and papers again!
Fun-O-Meter: 4

Competitors:
1. Jeep Liberty
2. Honda CR-V
3. Mitsubishi Outlander
4. Toyota RAV4

Cool Tech Items:
1. Google Local Search.
2. Micron air-filtration system.

Looks:
1. Sixteen-inch steel or alloy wheels; eighteen-inch aluminum-alloy wheels.
2. Satin nickel accented interior trim.

New for 2013:
1. New front fascia and grille design.
2. New turn signals and exterior colors.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CL Class
subTitle: Offering style and speed while exceeding the technological capability of some developing countries.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CL Class
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CL Class
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CL Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CL Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: This large and stylish coupe offers remarkable performance, including surprisingly good handling characteristics. With the base turbocharged 4.6-liter V-8 making 429 horsepower, the CL550 will perform as well as a sports car on a challenging road. A larger and even more powerful V-8 in the CL63 AMG is the favorite among four engines offered, although buyers might disagree and choose either of the two turbocharged V-12 powerplants. The larger, 6.0-liter one affords you the opportunity to play with 621 horsepower. Five- or seven-speed automatic transmissions are offered. If you’re planning on snowy winters, you should keep in mind that the CL550 is the only all-wheel-drive model. The exterior design is highlighted by pillarless construction that leaves an undefiled sweep of side glass. Body colors are subdued and dignified. Besides being exquisitely beautiful inside, the car is loaded with amenities. Heated and ventilated front seats offer a massaging capability, for example. Every conceivable active safety system is available, helping the driver to stay awake, see their blind spots, distinguish pedestrians at night, and keep the car in its lane. Some developing countries yearn for this kind of power and technological capability.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Aston Martin DB9
2. Bentley Continental GT
3. Maserati GranTurismo

Cool Tech:
1. Attention Assist “reads” steering input and other factors to create a driver profile, then steps in with audible warnings when appropriate.
2. Spotlight Function uses infrared beams to detect roadside pedestrians and then flash light from the headlamps on them.
3. Splitview dual-content display screen allows the driver to see navigation information while the front passenger watches a movie, listening to the sound through a wireless headset.

Looks
1. Pillarless hardtop design sleekens the profile.
2. Top-stitched leather and hand-polished wood are found throughout the interior.
3. The aggressive stance is accentuated by available nineteen- and twenty-inch wheels.

New for 2013
1. Grand Edition Package adds three custom exterior and interior colors.
2. Twenty-inch wheels available with Grand Edition package.
3. AMG styling also available with Grand Edition package.

title: 2013 Smart ForTwo
subTitle: A small car for big cities
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Smart ForTwo
promoTeaser: 2013 Smart ForTwo
metaTitle: 2013 Smart ForTwo Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Smart ForTwo here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Smart is still a curiosity in the American market, despite the increasing manufacture of ultracompact and electric cars. The Smart ForTwo is great for what it was designed for – short trips in big cities where parking and gas are too expensive to warrant a full-sized vehicle. It does a fantastic job of parking in tight spaces, and can park with its nose to the curb where a normal car would have to parallel park. The gas mileage is good – 34 mpg in the city, 38 mpg on the highway – but not a huge jump over some fuel-efficient or hybrid sedans. The Smart makes up for this by being much cheaper than most hybrids, starting just above $13,000. The very small package assumes certain sacrifices, and the long-legged among us might feel claustrophobic in the Smart’s tiny interior. Luckily, a convertible model is available for those who like to feel the breeze in their hair or need extra headroom. Smart made the wise choice of keeping the interior sparse and not cluttering the already tight space. With a top speed under 70 mph, the Smart won’t get your blood pumping, but it is a good option for city dwellers, and fits well with an environment-friendly lifestyle.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. Fiat 500
2. Mitsubishi i
3. Scion iQ

Cool Tech:
1. Best fuel rating of any gas automobile.
2. Convertible top can raise while moving.
3. Made of 85 percent recyclable material.

Looks:
1. Interchangeable body panels for constant color changing.
2. Clean interior with bright trim.
3. Many color choices.

New for 2013:
1. New electric model expected to extend range.
2. Electric motor increases top speed in that model.

title: 2013 Scion tC
subTitle: A two-door Scion for the street racers among us
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Scion tC
promoTeaser: 2013 Scion tC
metaTitle: 2013 Scion tC Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Scion tC here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Scion tC is smaller and faster than most of Scion’s other boxy offerings. With one of Scion’s most powerful engines, two doors, five seats, and a hatchback, the tC is the slightly more practical choice for people who can’t commit to the enviable FR-S. This is not to suggest that the tC is in any way boring. It is quick to accelerate and comes in a limited-run RS model (available only in “Absolutely Red’) that features a racy body kit and some Toyota Racing Development enhancements.  A six-speed transmission adds fuel efficiency, helping the tC inch its way above 30 miles to the gallon on the highway. The tC’s fabric seats are less than attractive, but the rest of the interior is pleasing, and the power moonroof is a nice touch. New for this model are standard Bluetooth and a Pioneer audio system. As with all Scions, the base package is just the beginning, with available after-market upgrades ranging from high performance air filters to illuminated doorsills. With a base price just under $20,000, the tC is one of Scion’s most expensive models. But with strong performance and a touch more sophistication than the brand’s other youth-mobiles, it is still a good choice.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Honda CR-Z
2. Hyundai Veloster
3. Kia Forte Koup

Cool Tech:
1. Six-speed transmission increases fuel efficiency.
2. Standard Pioneer audio system.
3. Available navigation system and XM Satellite Radio.

Looks:
1. Aggressive exterior design.
2. RS comes with body kit.
3. Many aftermarket accessories available.

New for 2013:
1. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.
2. 2013 Release Series 8.0, only 2,000 distributed.

title: 2013 Rolls-Royce Ghost
subTitle: If you’ve got the money, you won’t regret the Ghost.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Rolls-Royce Ghost
promoTeaser: 2013 Rolls-Royce Ghost
metaTitle: 2013 Rolls-Royce Ghost Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Rolls-Royce Ghost here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Despite being the smallest car that calls itself a Rolls-Royce, you won’t be cramped in this roving palace, especially not if you spring for the Extended Wheelbase edition, which comes with a standard panoramic sunroof. If you’re spending upwards of a quarter of a million dollars on a car, you want it to be perfect, and to that end, Rolls-Royce has engineered an automobile so smooth that you may think you’re floating through the crowds instead of travelling on the same roads as the rest of us. The leather-lined cabin is the last word in comfort and luxury, and with the aggressive, distinctive grille, your status as the owner of a Rolls will be broadcast to everyone you see. If you prefer your luxury a little more personalized, Rolls-Royce has a bespoke department to meet those needs. More than half of Ghosts sold in 2011 had bespoke elements. The Ghost comes with coach doors (suicide doors to the déclassé), for maximum exiting ease to chauffeured passengers. Because despite the Ghost’s impressive performance (0 to 60 mph in less than five seconds) this car may be one of the few that is best enjoyed from the back seat.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competition:
1. Bentley Mulsanne

Looks:
1. Available two-tone.
2. Panoramic sunroof standard with extended wheelbase version.
3. Soft leather interior.

Cool Tech:
1. Night Vision can recognize pedestrians and prepare the brakes for emergency stopping.
2. Available technology allows trunk to be opened with a leg movement, in case hands are too full to push buttons.

New for 2013:
1. Available perforated leather headliner.
2. Available natural grain leather seats.

title: 2013 Ram 1500
subTitle: This revised pickup is more than a butch exterior; it has an air suspension and an eight-speed transmission, and it gets 25 mpg on the highway.
promoTeaserSmall: This revised pickup is more than a butch exterior; it has an air suspension and an eight-speed transmission, and it gets 25 mpg on the highway.
promoTeaser: This revised pickup is more than a butch exterior; it has an air suspension and an eight-speed transmission, and it gets 25 mpg on the highway.
metaTitle: 2013 Ram 1500 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Ram 1500 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Chrysler is proud of the fact that its 2013 Ram 1500 full-size pickup truck has been rated at 25 mpg on the highway, best in its cohort. That good news continues with the Ram’s new grille and fascia, a more powerful V-6 engine, and an eight-speed automatic transmission—which has an interesting e-shift dial instead of floor or column shifters. There’s a nod to aerodynamics with grille shutters and an air suspension that has five height settings, including two for off-road applications. The Ram 1500 also has a fuel-saving stop-start system that shuts the engine off when the truck comes to a stop, then restarts it automatically. Add to that a set of low-rolling-resistance tires, another way to improve fuel economy, and you can see how the Ram came up with class-leading mpg. A V-8 engine is still on offer, too, for those so inclined. Inside, the half-ton Ram gets the latest UConnect Access telematics with an 8.4-inch touchscreen; it has a wireless connection built in, which lets you open and start the truck remotely using Internet or smartphone and use voice commands for phone, text, navigation, and music, not to mention hook up to a variety of online services. There’s HD radio as well, a first for the Ram. All that, and a price only one percent higher than the outgoing model at $23,585 including destination for the base model.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Silverado 1500
2. Ford F-150
3. Nissan Titan
4. Toyota Tundra

Cool Tech Items:
1. Air suspension
2. Rotary e-shift dial on eight-speed transmission

Looks
1. New colors for 2013: monotone or two-tone Black Gold, Copperhead, Maximum Steel Metallic, Prairie, and Western Brown.

New for 2013:
1. 6’4” bed option on Crew Cab – allows you to have the largest cab with the largest four-door body style and the largest bed option.

title: 2013 Ford Shelby GT500
promoTeaserSmall: The Carroll Shelby label means it’s hot and spicy.
promoTeaser: The Carroll Shelby label means it’s hot and spicy.
metaTitle: 2013 Ford Shelby GT500 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Check out Jean's review of the 2013 Ford Shelby GT500 here at Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Carroll Shelby name is not just badging where I'm concerned. Shelby and I were friends for many years, as you'll hear in my video review of the Shelby GT500. Shelby died last May 10 at the age of eighty-nine. So this year especially, it's fitting that this is the most powerful Mustang ever made--and a major piece of ammunition in the ongoing Camaro vs. Mustang performance-car wars.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/eqPWoiU0Yvc?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The top-of-the-line price for this car is above $68,000 with the addition of options and packages. They include a $3,495 SVT Performance package that bundles Torsen differential, 19-inch forged aluminum front wheels, 20-inch forged aluminum rear wheels, SVT Bilstein cockpit-selectable dampers, unique gearshift knob, and rear springs. A $2,340 electronics package bundles a navigation system, HD radio, and dual-zone climate control. Smaller items include a $375 vehicle cover, a $207 set of illuminated doorsills, $113 each for side scoops, and a $60 ash cup (!). The model you see here also has Le Mans top stripes and rocker stripes, Brembo brakes, a quad exhaust, and a power cloth top.

Standard safety features on the Shelby GT500 include four airbags, anti-lock brakes, traction control, and stability control. A new "productivity screen" in the dash includes an accelerometer that shows the g-force the car is pulling from left to right. You can also track fastest times with the acceleration timer screen.

But what you really want to hear about is power, isn't it? The Shelby GT500 beats the base Mustang by 357 horsepower: it's 662 hp vs. 305 hp. This is not your commuter car, but it could be your track car.

title: 2012 Mini Cooper Countryman
promoTeaserSmall: Four-door Mini is ideal for my country pursuits.
promoTeaser: Four-door Mini is ideal for my country pursuits.
metaTitle: 2012 Mini Cooper Countryman - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Check out my review of the 2012 MINI Cooper Countryman here on Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The 2012 Mini Cooper S Countryman All4 is a way to have your small car and also have the ability to travel with baggage and companions, such as a dog, for example. This is the practical Mini for those who need more space and more spice than the competition (including the Chevrolet Cruze and Toyota Corolla) can offer. It's got the Kia Soul and Nissan Leaf as competitors, too.
The contrasting roof is a Mini tradition, designed to help the car stand out from the pack at rallies.

The Countryman is 5.5 inches longer than the three-door Mini Clubman. The base car has rear seats that slide back and forth to provide more cargo room, but cargo room is still not great. Fuel economy is decent at a combined 27 mpg for the model with six-speed manual transmission.

You can dress up your Mini, and yourself, with plentiful options such as eighteen-inch wheels, dual-pane sunroof, premium audio, and custom graphics and trim--and for yourself, Mini Countryman boots with a Union Jack design, a parka, a lilac T-shirt with the Mini logo...the list goes on all the way to a wooden chair in racing livery with a Union Jack to match the car.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/E9kIFnASWL0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The S version of the Countryman is a performance model, with a turbocharged version of the same 181-horsepower engine. You can also get it, as here, with all-wheel drive.

title: 2013 Nissan Versa
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Versa is a must-see for those on a quest for the cheapest car.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Nissan Versa is a must-see for those on a quest for the cheapest car.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Nissan Versa is a must-see for those on a quest for the cheapest car.
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Versa Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Versa here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: It’s anybody’s guess whether the 2013 Nissan Versa sedan will hang onto its title of cheapest car in America, since pricing has not been announced yet. But Versa was the Holy Grail when it came to inexpensive cars last year after Hyundai walked away from the fight over such a title with its redesigned Accent. The base 2012 Versa sedan with a five-speed manual transmission starts at a remarkable $11,770, including a $780 destination charge. Nissan redesigned the Versa sedan for 2012 and it still has appeal for those shopping for the best value. The Versa also comes in a hatchback version, which has yet to undergo a major revision and is a carryover from the 2012 model year. The Versa sedan has much to recommend it since highway fuel economy increases to 40 mpg this year on CVT-equipped models. The sedan is equipped with a 109-horsepower 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine. A Versa sedan with a four-speed automatic transmission is new for 2013. Different trim levels on the sedan also add new features for 2013, including the addition of a rear spoiler on CVT-equipped models and goodies like a remote key fob trunk release on SL models.  In addition to excellent value, the sedan also has a huge trunk and plenty of ride comfort. On the downside, acceleration is acceptable, but not thrilling. If you’re into extreme couponing, stockpiling toilet paper, and penny pinching, the Versa should be on your shopping list.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Sonic
2. Ford Fiesta
3. Honda Fit
4. Hyundai Accent

New for 2013:
1. Versa sedan 1.6 S AT model added with four-speed automatic transmission.
2. SV Convenience Package adds 60/40-split rear seat.
3. SL Tech Package adds RearView Monitor.
4. CVT-equipped models add rear spoiler.
5. SV models add cloth door trim, chromed interior door handles, and painted shift knob, driver’s seat armrest.
6. SL models add Intelligent Key, remote key fob trunk release, sun visor extensions, driver’s seat armrest, and immobilizer.
7. S models add trunk light.
8. Highway fuel economy increases from 38 to 40 mpg on CVT-equipped models.

title: 2013 GMC Yukon
subTitle: If you think size really does matter (when it comes to SUVs, anyway), GMC has a mega-ute for you.
promoTeaserSmall: If you think size really does matter (when it comes to SUVs, anyway), GMC has a mega-ute for you.
promoTeaser: If you think size really does matter (when it comes to SUVs, anyway), GMC has a mega-ute for you.
metaTitle: 2013 GMC Yukon Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 GMC Yukon here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: While the automotive world seems to be focusing on downsizing and raising fuel economy, the market for full-size SUVs is still vibrant. GMC’s Yukon and its long-wheelbase Yukon XL are getting a little long in the tooth, but they still have few peers in the art of shuttling people, hauling things, or towing trailers—or doing all three simultaneously—with space and style. On the Yukon’s long list of goodies are cool, fold-and-tumble second-row seats with one-handed operation, as well as OnStar and standard third-row seating. A Heritage edition is offered in blue, black, or white, and features twenty-inch wheels, exterior and interior commemorative badging, content upgrades and more, while the Denali model turns the Yukon into a poor man’s Cadillac Escalade. Well, not too poor of a man, as the bling-u-vee model’s signature perforated chrome grille, huge twenty- or twenty-two-inch wheels, upgraded interior materials, Nuance leather upholstery, surround sound audio system, power-release second-row tumbling seats, remote start, rear camera and park assist certainly don’t come for free. But they do add some serious pizzazz to GM’s hardy mega-ute, whether they be standard, XL, or hybrid varieties. Yes, we said “hybrid.” GM builds a hybrid version of this beast, which makes little sense for country folks, but with a third better city fuel economy, urban-dwelling Yukon intenders may want to snatch one up soon as they’re rumored to be on the chopping block when the next-gen model arrives, likely next year.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Suburban
2. Ford Expedition
3. Toyota Sequoia

Cool Tech Items:
1. Two-mode hybrid model with 33 percent better city fuel economy.
2. Slight fuel economy improvement with cylinder deactivation.
3. Yukon XL offered as heavy duty model.

Looks:
1. Unique wheels, upgraded interior on swan song Heritage edition.
2. Chrome-heavy exterior trim, luxury-laden interior on fancy schmancy Denali model.
3. Aero accents, H-Y-B-R-I-D decals on Hybrid model.

New for 2013:
1. Powertrain grade braking in normal transmission mode (versus tow/haul mode).
2. Champagne Silver exterior color.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Tahoe
subTitle: Suburban’s smaller sibling has the same big Chevy heart, just not as big a footprint.
